12 I am become a reproach among all my enemies, and very much to my neighbours; and a fear to my acquaintance. They that saw me without fled from me. 12 apud omnes hostes meos factus sum obprobrium et vicinis meis nimis et timor notis meis qui videbant me in plateis fugiebant me
13 I am forgotten as one dead from the heart. I am become as a vessel that is destroyed. 13 oblivioni traditus sum quasi mortuus a corde factus sum quasi vas perditum
14 For I have heard the blame of many that dwell round about. While they assembled together against me, they consulted to take away my life. 14 audivi enim obprobrium multorum congregationem in circuitu cum inirent consilium adversum me et ut auferrent animam meam cogitarent
15 But I have put my trust in thee, O Lord: I said: Thou art my God. 15 ego autem in te speravi Domine dixi Deus meus es tu
16 My lots are in thy hands. Deliver me out of the hands of my enemies; and from them that persecute me. 16 in manu tua tempora mea libera me de manu inimicorum meorum et persequentium me
17 Make thy face to shine upon thy servant; save me in thy mercy. 17 ostende faciem tuam super servum tuum salva me in misericordia tua
18 Let me not be confounded, O Lord, for I have called upon thee. Let the wicked be ashamed, and be brought down to hell. 18 Domine ne confundar quia invocavi te confundantur impii taceant in inferno
19 Let deceitful lips be made dumb. Which speak iniquity against the just, with pride and abuse. 19 muta fiant labia mendacii quae loquuntur contra iustum vetera in superbia et despectione
20 O how great is the multitude of thy sweetness, O Lord, which thou hast hidden for them that fear thee! Which thou hast wrought for them that hope in thee, in the sight of the sons of men. 20 quam multa est bonitas tua quam abscondisti timentibus te operatus es sperantibus in te in conspectu filiorum hominum
21 Thou shalt hide them in the secret of thy face, from the disturbance of men. Thou shalt protect them in thy tabernacle from the contradiction of tongues. 21 abscondes eos in protectione vultus tui a duritia viri abscondes eos in umbra a contradictione linguarum
22 Blessed be the Lord, for he hath shewn his wonderful mercy to me in a fortified city. 22 benedictus Dominus qui mirabilem fecit misericordiam suam mihi in civitate munita
23 But I said in the excess of my mind: I am cast away from before thy eyes. Therefore thou hast heard the voice of my prayer, when I cried to thee. 23 ego autem dixi in stupore meo proiectus sum de conspectu oculorum eius ergone audisti vocem deprecationis meae cum clamarem ad te
24 O love the Lord, all ye his saints: for the Lord will require truth, and will repay them abundantly that act proudly. 24 diligite Dominum omnes sancti eius fideles servat Dominus et retribuet his qui satis operantur superbiam
25 Do ye manfully, and let your heart be strengthened, all ye that hope in the Lord. 25 confortamini et roboretur cor vestrum omnes qui expectatis Dominum

Chapter 31

Beati quorum. The second penitential psalm.

1 To David himself, understanding. Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered. 1 David eruditi beatus cui dimissa est iniquitas et absconditum est peccatum
2 Blessed is the man to whom the Lord hath not imputed sin, and in whose spirit there is no guile. 2 beatus homo cui non inputabit Dominus iniquitatem nec est in spiritu eius dolus
3 Because I was silent my bones grew old; whilst I cried out all the day long. 3 quia tacui adtrita sunt ossa mea in rugitu meo tota die
4 For day and night thy hand was heavy upon me: I am turned in my anguish, whilst the thorn is fastened. 4 die enim et nocte gravatur super me manus tua versatus sum in miseria mea cum exardesceret messis iugiter
5 I have acknowledged my sin to thee, and my injustice I have not concealed. I said I will confess against my self my injustice to the Lord: and thou hast forgiven the wickedness of my sin. 5 peccatum meum notum facio tibi et iniquitatem meam non abscondo dixi confitebor scelus meum Domino et tu dimisisti iniquitatem peccati mei semper
6 For this shall every one that is holy pray to thee in a seasonable time. And yet in a flood of many waters, they shall not come nigh unto him. 6 pro hoc orat omnis sanctus ad te tempus inveniens ut cum inundaverint aquae multae ad illum non accedant
7 Thou art my refuge from the trouble which hath encompassed me: my joy, deliver me from them that surround me. 7 tu es protectio mea ab hoste custodies me laus mea salvans circumdabis me semper
8 I will give thee understanding, and I will instruct thee in this way, in which thou shalt go: I will fix my eyes upon thee. 8 doceam te et monstrabo tibi viam per quam ambules cogitabo de te oculo meo
9 Do not become like the horse and the mule, who have no understanding. With bit and bridle bind fast their jaws, who come not near unto thee. 9 nolite fieri sicut equus et mulus quibus non est intellegentia in camo et freno maxillas eorum constringe qui non accedunt ad te
10 Many are the scourges of the sinner, but mercy shall encompass him that hopeth in the Lord. 10 multi dolores impii confidentem autem in Domino misericordia circumdabit
11 Be glad in the Lord, and rejoice, ye just, and glory, all ye right of heart. 11 laetamini in Domino et exultate iusti et laudate omnes recti corde

Chapter 32

Exultate, justi. An exhortation to praise God, and to trust in him.

1 A psalm for David. Rejoice in the Lord, O ye just: praise becometh the upright. 1 laudate iusti Dominum rectos decet laudatio
2 Give praise to the Lord on the harp; sing to him with the psaltery, the instrument of ten strings. 2 confitemini Domino in cithara in psalterio decacordo cantate ei
3 Sing to him a new canticle, sing well unto him with a loud noise. 3 cantate ei canticum novum diligenter psallite in iubilo
4 For the word of the Lord is right, and all his works are done with faithfulness. 4 quia rectum est verbum Domini et omne opus eius in fide
5 He loveth mercy and judgment; the earth is full of the mercy of the Lord. 5 diligit iustitiam et iudicium misericordia Domini plena est terra
6 By the word of the Lord the heavens were established; and all the power of them by the spirit of his mouth: 6 verbo Domini caeli facti sunt et spiritu oris eius omnis ornatus eorum
7 Gathering together the waters of the sea, as in a vessel; laying up the depths in storehouses. 7 congregans quasi in utre aquas maris ponens in thesauris abyssos
8 Let all the earth fear the Lord, and let all the inhabitants of the world be in awe of him. 8 timeat Dominum omnis terra ipsum formident universi habitatores orbis
9 For he spoke and they were made: he commanded and they were created. 9 quia ipse mandavit et factus est ipso praecipiente stetit
10 The Lord bringeth to nought the counsels of nations; and he rejecteth the devices of people, and casteth away the counsels of princes. 10 Dominus dissolvit consilium gentium irritas fecit cogitationes populorum
11 But the counsel of the Lord standeth for ever: the thoughts of his heart to all generations. 11 consilium Domini in aeternum stabit cogitationes cordis eius in generatione et generatione
12 Blessed is the nation whose God is the Lord: the people whom he hath chosen for his inheritance. 12 beata gens cuius Dominus Deus eius populus quem elegit in hereditatem sibi
13 The Lord hath looked from heaven: he hath beheld all the sons of men. 13 de caelo respexit Dominus vidit omnes filios Adam
14 From his habitation which he hath prepared, he hath looked upon all that dwell on the earth. 14 de firmissimo solio suo prospexit ad universos habitatores terrae
15 He who hath made the hearts of every one of them: who understandeth all their works. 15 fingens pariter cor eorum intellegens omnia opera eorum
16 The king is not saved by a great army: nor shall the giant be saved by his own great strength. 16 non salvatur rex in multitudine exercitus nec fortis liberabitur in multiplicatione virtutis
17 Vain is the horse for safety: neither shall he be saved by the abundance of his strength. 17 fallax equus ad salutem et in multitudine roboris sui non salvabit
18 Behold the eyes of the Lord are on them that fear him: and on them that hope in his mercy. 18 ecce oculus Domini super timentes eum et expectantes misericordiam eius
19 To deliver their souls from death; and feed them in famine. 19 ut eruat de morte animam eorum et vivificet eos in fame
20 Our soul waiteth for the Lord: for he is our helper and protector. 20 anima nostra expectavit Dominum auxilium nostrum et clipeus noster est
21 For in him our heart shall rejoice: and in his holy name we have trusted. 21 in ipso enim laetabitur cor nostrum quia in nomine sancto eius speravimus
22 Let thy mercy, O Lord, be upon us, as we have hooped in thee. 22 sit misericordia tua Domine super nos sicut expectavimus te

Chapter 33

Benedicam Dominum. An exhortation to the praise, and service of God.

1 For David, when he changed his countenance before Achimelech, who dismissed him, and he went his way. [1 Kings 21.] 1 David quando commutavit os suum coram Abimelech et eiecit eum et abiit
2 I will bless the Lord at all times, his praise shall be always in my mouth. 2 benedicam Domino in omni tempore semper laus eius in ore meo
3 In the Lord shall my soul be praised: let the meek hear and rejoice. 3 in Domino laetabitur anima mea audiant mites et laetentur
4 O magnify the Lord with me; and let us extol his name together. 4 magnificate Dominum mecum et exaltemus nomen eius pariter
5 I sought the Lord, and he heard me; and he delivered me from all my troubles. 5 quaesivi Dominum et exaudivit me et de omnibus angustiis meis liberavit me
6 Come ye to him and be enlightened: and your faces shall not be confounded. 6 respicite ad eum et confluite et vultus vestri non confundentur
7 This poor man cried, and the Lord heard him: and saved him out of all his troubles. 7 hic pauper clamavit et Dominus exaudivit de omnibus tribulationibus salvabit eum
8 The angel of the Lord shall encamp round about them that fear him: and shall deliver them. 8 circumdat angelus Domini in gyro timentes eum et eruet eos
9 O taste, and see that the Lord is sweet: blessed is the man that hopeth in him. 9 gustate et videte quoniam bonus Dominus beatus vir qui sperat in eo
10 Fear the Lord, all ye his saints: for there is no want to them that fear him. 10 timete Dominum sancti eius quoniam non est inopia timentibus eum
11 The rich have wanted, and have suffered hunger: but they that seek the Lord shall not be deprived of any good. 11 leones indiguerunt et esurierunt quaerentibus autem Dominum non deerit omne bonum
12 Come, children, hearken to me: I will teach you the fear of the Lord. 12 venite filii audite me timorem Domini docebo vos
13 Who is the man that desireth life: who liveth to see good days? 13 quis est vir qui velit vitam diligens dies videre bonos
14 Keep thy tongue form evil, and thy lips from speaking guile. 14 custodi linguam tuam a malo et labia tua ne loquantur dolum
15 Turn away from evil and do good: seek after peace and pursue it. 15 recede a malo et fac bonum quaere pacem et persequere eam
16 The eyes of the Lord are upon the just: and his ears unto their prayers. 16 oculi Domini ad iustos et aures eius ad clamorem eorum
17 But the countenance of the Lord is against them that do evil things: to cut off the remembrance of them from the earth. 17 vultus Domini super facientes malum ut perdat de terra memoriam eorum
18 The just cried, and the Lord heard them: and delivered them out of all their troubles. 18 clamaverunt et Dominus exaudivit et ex omnibus tribulationibus eorum liberavit eos
19 The Lord is nigh unto them that are of a contrite heart: and he will save the humble of spirit. 19 iuxta est Dominus contritis corde et confractos spiritu salvabit
20 Many are the afflictions of the just; but out of them all will the Lord deliver them. 20 multae tribulationes iusti et ex omnibus illis liberabit eum Dominus
21 The Lord is nigh unto them that are of a contrite heart: and he will save the humble of spirit. 21 custodit omnia ossa eius unum ex eis non confringetur
22 The death of the wicked is very evil: and they that hate the just shall be guilty. 22 interficiet impium malitia et odientes iustum superabuntur
23 The Lord will redeem the souls of his servants: and none of them that trust in him shall offend. 23 redimet Dominus animam servorum suorum et non peccabunt omnes sperantes in eo

Chapter 34

Judica, Domine, nocentes me. David, in the person of Christ, prayeth against his persecutors: prophetically foreshewing the punishments that shall fall upon them.

1 For David himself. Judge thou, O Lord, them that wrong me: overthrow them that fight against me. 1 David iudica Domine adversarios meos pugna contra pugnantes me
2 Take hold of arms and shield: and rise up to help me. 2 adprehende scutum et hastam et consurge in auxilium meum
3 Bring out the sword, and shut up the way against them that persecute me: say to my soul: I am thy salvation. 3 evagina gladium et praeoccupa ex adverso persequentem me dic animae meae salus tua ego sum
4 Let them be confounded and ashamed that seek after my soul. Let them be turned back and be confounded that devise evil against me. 4 confundantur et revereantur qui quaerunt animam meam convertantur retrorsum et confundantur qui cogitant malum mihi
5 Let them become as dust before the wind: and let the angel of the Lord straiten them. 5 fiant sicut pulvis ante faciem venti et angelus Domini inpellat
6 Let their way become dark and slippery; and let the angel of the Lord pursue them. 6 sit via eorum tenebrae et lubricum et angelus Domini persequatur eos
7 For without cause they have hidden their net for me unto destruction: without cause they have upbraided my soul. 7 quia frustra absconderunt mihi insidias retis sui sine causa foderunt animae meae
8 Let the snare which he knoweth not come upon him: and let the net which he hath hidden catch him: and into that very snare let them fall. 8 veniat ei calamitas quam ignorat et rete suum quod abscondit conprehendat eum et cadat in laqueum
9 But my soul shall rejoice in the Lord; and shall be delighted in his salvation. 9 anima autem mea exultabit in Domino et laetabitur in salute sua
10 All my bones shall say: Lord, who is like to thee? Who deliverest the poor from the hand of them that are stronger than he; the needy and the poor from them that strip him. 10 omnia ossa mea dicent Domine quis similis tui eruens inopem a validiore et pauperem et mendicum a violento
11 Unjust witnesses rising up have asked me things I knew not. 11 surgentes testes iniqui quae nesciebam interrogabant me
12 They repaid me evil for good: to the depriving me of my soul. 12 reddebant mihi mala pro bono sterilitatem animae meae
13 But as for me, when they were troublesome to me, I was clothed with haircloth. I humbled my soul with fasting; and my prayer shall be turned into my bosom. 13 ego autem cum infirmarer ab eis induebar cilicio humiliabam in ieiunio animam meam et oratio mea ad sinum meum revertetur
14 As a neighbour and as an own brother, so did I please: as one mourning and sorrowful so was I humbled. 14 quasi ad amicum quasi ad fratrem meum sic ambulabam quasi lugens mater tristis incurvabar
15 But they rejoiced against me, and came together: scourges were gathered together upon me, and I knew not. 15 et in infirmitate mea laetabantur et congregabantur collecti sunt adversum me percutientes et nesciebam
16 They were separated, and repented not: they tempted me, they scoffed at me with scorn: they gnashed upon me with their teeth. 16 scindentes et non tacentes in simulatione verborum fictorum frendebant contra me dentibus suis
17 Lord, when wilt thou look upon me? rescue thou my soul from their malice: my only one from the lions. 17 Domine quanta aspicies converte animam meam a calamitatibus suis a leonibus solitariam meam
18 I will give thanks to thee in a great church; I will praise thee in a strong people. 18 confitebor tibi in ecclesia grandi in populo forti laudabo te
19 Let not them that are my enemies wrongfully rejoice over me: who have hated me without cause, and wink with the eyes. 19 non laetentur super me inimici mei mendaces odientes me frustra coniventes oculo
20 For they spoke indeed peaceably to me; and speaking in the anger of the earth they devised guile. 20 non enim pacem loquuntur sed in rapina terrae verba fraudulenta concinnant
21 And they opened their mouth wide against me; they said: Well done, well done, our eyes have seen it. 21 et dilataverunt super me os suum dixerunt va va vidit oculus noster
22 Thou hast seen, O Lord, be not thou silent: O Lord, depart not from me. 22 vidisti Domine ne taceas Domine ne elongeris a me
23 Arise, and be attentive to my judgment: to my cause, my God, and my Lord. 23 consurge et evigila in iudicium meum Deus meus et Domine in causam meam
24 Judge me, O Lord my God according to thy justice, and let them not rejoice over me. 24 iudica me secundum iustitiam meam Domine Deus meus et ne insultent mihi
25 Let them not say in their hearts: It is well, it is well, to our mind: neither let them say: We have swallowed him up. 25 ne dicant in corde suo va va va animae nostrae ne dicant absorbuimus eum
26 Let them blush: and be ashamed together, who rejoice at my evils. Let them be clothed with confusion and shame, who speak great things against me. 26 confundantur et revereantur pariter qui laetantur in adflictione mea induantur confusione et verecundia qui magnificantur super me
27 Let them rejoice and be glad, who are well pleased with my justice, and let them say always: The Lord be magnified, who delights in the peace of his servant. 27 laudent et laetentur qui volunt iustitiam meam et dicant semper magnificetur Dominus qui vult pacem servi sui
28 And my tongue shall meditate thy justice, thy praise all the day long. 28 et lingua mea meditabitur iustitiam tuam tota die laudem tuam

Chapter 35

Dixit injustus. The malice of sinners, and the goodness of God.

1 Unto the end, for the servant of God, David himself. 1 pro victoria servi Domini David
2 The unjust hath said within himself, that he would sin: there is no fear of God before his eyes. 2 dixit scelus impii in medio cordis eius non esse timorem Dei ante oculos eius
3 For in his sight he hath done deceitfully, that his iniquity may be found unto hatred. 3 quia dolose egit adversum eum in oculis suis ut inveniret iniquitatem eius ad odiendum
4 The words of his mouth are iniquity and guile: he would not understand that he might do well. 4 verba oris eius iniquitas et dolus cessavit cogitare benefacere
5 He hath devised iniquity on his bed, he hath set himself on every way that is not good: but evil he hath not hated. 5 iniquitatem cogitat in cubili suo stabit in via non bona malum non abiciet
6 O Lord, thy mercy is in heaven, and thy truth reacheth even to the clouds. 6 Domine in caelo misericordia tua fides tua usque ad nubes
7 Thy justice is as the mountains of God, thy judgments are a great deep. Men and beasts thou wilt preserve, O Lord: 7 iustitia tua quasi montes Domine iudicium tuum abyssus multa homines et iumenta salvos facies Domine
8 O how hast thou multiplied thy mercy, O God! But the children of men shall put their trust under the covert of thy wings. 8 quam pretiosa est misericordia tua Domine et filii Adam in umbra alarum tuarum sperabunt
9 They shall be inebriated with the plenty of thy house; and thou shalt make them drink of the torrent of thy pleasure. 9 inebriabuntur de pinguidine domus tuae et torrente deliciarum tuarum potabis eos
10 For with thee is the fountain of life; and in thy light we shall see light. 10 quoniam tecum est fons vitae in lumine tuo videbimus lumen
11 Extend thy mercy to them that know thee, and thy justice to them that are right in heart. 11 adtrahe misericordiam tuam scientibus te et iustitiam tuam rectis corde
12 Let not the foot of pride come to me, and let not the hand of the sinner move me. 12 ne veniat mihi pes superbiae et manus impiorum non me commoveat
13 There the workers of iniquity are fallen, they are cast out, and could not stand. 13 ibi ceciderunt operantes iniquitatem expulsi sunt et non potuerunt surgere

Chapter 36

Noli aemulari. An exhortation to despise this world; and the short prosperity of the wicked; and to trust in Providence.

1 Be not emulous of evildoers; nor envy them that work iniquity. 1 David aleph noli contendere cum malignis neque aemuleris facientes iniquitatem
2 For they shall shortly wither away as grass, and as the green herbs shall quickly fall. 2 quoniam sicut herba velociter conterentur et sicut holus viride arescent
3 Trust in the Lord, and do good, and dwell in the land, and thou shalt be fed with its riches. 3 beth spera in Domino et fac bonum peregrinare in terra et pascere fide
4 Delight in the Lord, and he will give thee the requests of thy heart. 4 et delectare in Domino et dabit tibi petitiones cordis tui
5 Commit thy way to the Lord, and trust in him, and he will do it. 5 gimel volve super Dominum viam tuam et confide in eo et ipse faciet
6 And he will bring forth thy justice as the light, and thy judgment as the noonday. 6 et educet sicut lumen iustitiam tuam et iudicium tuum sicut meridiem
7 Be subject to the Lord and pray to him. Envy not the man who prospereth in his way; the man who doth unjust things. 7 deleth tace Domino et expecta eum noli contendere adversum eum qui proficit in via sua adversum virum qui facit quae cogitat
8 Cease from anger, and leave rage; have no emulation to do evil. 8 he dimitte iram et relinque furorem noli contendere ut malefacias
9 For evildoers shall be cut off: but they that wait upon the Lord, they shall inherit the land. 9 quoniam qui malefaciunt interibunt expectantes autem Dominum ipsi hereditabunt terram
10 For yet a little while, and the wicked shall not be: and thou shalt seek his place, and shalt not find it. 10 vav adhuc enim modicum et non erit impius et cogitabis de loco eius et non subsistet
11 But the meek shall inherit the land, and shall delight in abundance of peace. 11 mites autem hereditabunt terram et delectabuntur in multitudine pacis
12 The sinner shall watch the just man: and shall gnash upon him with his teeth. 12 zai cogitat impius de iusto et frendet adversum eum dentibus suis
13 But the Lord shall laugh at him: for he foreseeth that his day shall come. 13 Dominus deridebit eum videns quod venit dies eius
14 The wicked have drawn out the sword: they have bent their bow. To cast down the poor and needy, to kill the upright of heart. 14 heth gladium evaginaverunt impii tetenderunt arcum suum ut percutiant egenum et pauperem et interficiant rectos in via
15 Let their sword enter into their own hearts, and let their bow be broken. 15 gladius eorum ingrediatur in cor eorum et arcus eorum confringantur
16 Better is a little to the just, than the great riches of the wicked. 16 teth melius est parum iusto quam divitiae impiorum multae
17 For the arms of the wicked shall be broken in pieces; but the Lord strengtheneth the just. 17 quia brachia impiorum confringentur sublevat autem iustos Dominus
18 The Lord knoweth the days of the undefiled; and their inheritance shall be for ever. 18 ioth novit Dominus diem inmaculatorum et hereditas eorum aeterna erit
19 They shall not be confounded in the evil time; and in the days of famine they shall be filled: 19 non confundentur in tempore malo et in diebus famis saturabuntur
20 Because the wicked shall perish. And the enemies of the Lord, presently after they shall be honoured and exalted, shall come to nothing and vanish like smoke. 20 caph quia impii peribunt et inimici Domini gloriantes ut monocerotes consumentur sicut fumus consumitur
21 The sinner shall borrow, and not pay again; but the just sheweth mercy and shall give. 21 lameth fenus accipit impius et non reddit iustus autem donat et tribuit
22 For such as bless him shall inherit the land: but such as curse him shall perish. 22 quia qui benedicti fuerint ab eo hereditabunt terram et qui maledicti interibunt
23 With the Lord shall the steps of a man be directed, and he shall like well his way. 23 mem a Domino gressus viri firmantur et viam eius volet
24 When he shall fall he shall not be bruised, for the Lord putteth his hand under him. 24 cum ceciderit non adlidetur quia Dominus sustentat manum eius
25 I have been young and now am old; and I have not seen the just forsaken, nor his seed seeking bread. 25 nun puer fui siquidem senui et non vidi iustum derelictum neque semen eius quaerens panem
26 He sheweth mercy, and lendeth all the day long; and his seed shall be in blessing. 26 tota die donat et commodat et semen eius in benedictione
27 Decline from evil and do good, and dwell for ever and ever. 27 samech recede a malo et fac bonum et habita in sempiterno
28 For the Lord loveth judgment, and will not forsake his saints: they shall be preserved for ever. The unjust shall be punished, and the seed of the wicked shall perish. 28 quia Dominus diligit iudicium et non derelinquet sanctos suos ain in aeternum custoditi sunt et semen impiorum periit
29 But the just shall inherit the land, and shall dwell therein for evermore. 29 iusti hereditabunt terram et habitabunt in saeculum super eam
30 The mouth of the just shall meditate wisdom: and his tongue shall speak judgment. 30 fe os iusti meditabitur sapientiam et lingua eius loquetur iudicium
31 The law of his God is in his heart, and his steps shall not be supplanted. 31 lex Dei eius in corde eius non deficient gressus eius
32 The wicked watcheth the just man, and seeketh to put him to death, 32 sade considerat impius iustum et quaerit ut occidat eum
33 But the Lord will not leave him in his hands; nor condemn him when he shall be judged. 33 Dominus non derelinquet eum in manu eius et non condemnabit eum cum iudicatur
34 Expect the Lord and keep his way: and he will exalt thee to inherit the land: when the sinners shall perish thou shalt see. 34 coph expecta Dominum et custodi viam eius et exaltabit te ut possideas terram cum interibunt impii videbis
35 I have seen the wicked highly exalted, and lifted up like the cedars of Libanus. 35 res vidi impium robustum et fortissimum sicut indigenam virentem
36 And I passed by, and lo, he was not: and I sought him and his place was not found. 36 et transivi et ecce non erat et quaesivi eum et non est inventus
37 Keep innocence, and behold justice: for there are remnants for the peaceable man. 37 sen custodi simplicitatem et vide rectum quia erit ad extremum viro pax
38 But the unjust shall be destroyed together: the remnants of the wicked shall perish. 38 iniqui autem delebuntur pariter et novissimum impiorum peribit
39 But the salvation of the just is from the Lord, and he is their protector in the time of trouble. 39 thau salus iustorum a Domino fortitudo eorum in tempore tribulationis
40 And the Lord will help them and deliver them: and he will rescue them from the wicked, and save them because they have hoped in him. 40 et auxiliabitur eis Dominus et salvabit eos ab impiis quia speraverunt in eo

Chapter 37

Domine, ne in furore. A prayer of a penitent for the remission of his sins. The third penitential psalm.

1 A psalm for David, for a remembrance of the sabbath. 1 canticum David in commemoratione
2 Rebuke me not, O Lord, in thy indignation; nor chastise me in thy wrath. 2 Domine ne in ira tua arguas me neque in furore tuo corripias me
3 For thy arrows are fastened in me: and thy hand hath been strong upon me. 3 quia sagittae tuae infixae sunt mihi et tetigit me manus tua
4 There is no health in my flesh, because of thy wrath: there is no peace for my bones, because of my sins. 4 non est sanitas in carne mea a facie indignationis tuae non est pax ossibus meis a facie peccati mei
5 For my iniquities are gone over my head: and as a heavy burden are become heavy upon me. 5 quia iniquitates meae transierunt caput meum quasi onus grave adgravatae sunt super me
6 My sores are putrified and corrupted, because of my foolishness. 6 conputruerunt et tabuerunt cicatrices meae a facie insipientiae meae
7 I am become miserable, and am bowed down even to the end: I walked sorrowful all the day long. 7 adflictus sum et incurvatus nimis tota die maerens ambulabam
8 For my loins are filled with illusions; and there is no health in my flesh. 8 quia lumbi mei repleti sunt ignominia et non est sanitas in carne mea
9 I am afflicted and humbled exceedingly: I roared with the groaning of my heart. 9 evigilavi et adflictus sum nimis rugiebam a gemitu cordis mei
10 Lord, all my desire is before thee, and my groaning is not hidden from thee. 10 Domine in conspectu tuo omne desiderium meum et gemitus meus a te non est absconditus
11 My heart is troubled, my strength hath left me, and the light of my eyes itself is not with me. 11 cor meum fluctuabat dereliquit me fortitudo mea et lux oculorum meorum etiam ipsa non est mecum
12 My friends and my neighbours have drawn near, and stood against me. And they that were near me stood afar off: 12 cari mei et amici mei quasi contra lepram meam steterunt et vicini mei longe steterunt
13 And they that sought my soul used violence. And they that sought evils to me spoke vain things, and studied deceits all the day long. 13 et inruebant quaerentes animam meam et investigantes mala mihi loquebantur insidias et dolos tota die meditabantur
14 But I, as a deaf man, heard not: and as a dumb man not opening his mouth. 14 ego autem quasi surdus non audiebam et quasi mutus non aperiebam os meum
15 And I became as a man that heareth not: and that hath no reproofs in his mouth. 15 et eram quasi homo non audiens nec habens in ore suo redargutiones
16 For in thee, O Lord, have I hoped: thou wilt hear me, O Lord my God. 16 te enim Domine expectabam tu exaudies Domine Deus meus
17 For I said: Lest at any time my enemies rejoice over me: and whilst my feet are moved, they speak great things against me. 17 quia dixi ne forte insultent mihi et cum vacillaverint pedes mei super me magnificentur
18 For I am ready for scourges: and my sorrow is continually before me. 18 quia ego ad plagas paratus et dolor meus contra me est semper
19 For I will declare my iniquity: and I will think for my sin. 19 quia iniquitatem meam adnuntio sollicitus ero pro peccato meo
20 But my enemies live, and are stronger than I: and they that hate me wrongfully are multiplied. 20 inimici autem mei viventes confortati sunt et multiplicati sunt odientes me mendaciter
21 They that render evil for good, have detracted me, because I followed goodness. 21 et qui reddunt malum pro bono adversabantur mihi quia sequebar bonum
22 For sake me not, O Lord my God: do not thou depart from me. 22 ne derelinquas me Domine Deus meus ne elongeris a me
23 Attend unto my help, O Lord, the God of my salvation. 23 festina in auxilium meum Domine salutis meae

Chapter 38

Dixi custodiam. A just man's peace and patience in his sufferings; considering the vanity of the world, and the providence of God.

1 Unto the end, for Idithun himself, a canticle of David. 1 pro victoria Idithun canticum David
2 I said: I will take heed to my ways: that I sin not with my tongue. I have set a guard to my mouth, when the sinner stood against me. 2 dixi custodiam vias meas ne peccem in lingua mea custodiam os meum silentio donec est impius contra me
3 I was dumb, and was humbled, and kept silence from good things: and my sorrow was renewed. 3 obmutui silentio tacui de bono et dolor meus conturbatus est
4 My heart grew hot within me: and in my meditation a fire shall flame out. 4 incaluit cor meum in medio mei in meditatione mea incensus sum igni
5 I spoke with my tongue: O Lord, make me know my end. And what is the number of my days: that I may know what is wanting to me. 5 locutus sum lingua mea ostende mihi Domine finem meum et mensuram dierum meorum quae sit ut sciam quid mihi desit
6 Behold thou hast made my days measurable. and my substance is as nothing before thee. And indeed all things are vanity: every man living. 6 ecce breves posuisti dies meos et vita mea quasi non sit in conspectu tuo omnia enim vanitas omnis homo stans semper
7 Surely man passeth as an image: yea, and he is disquieted in vain. He storeth up: and he knoweth not for whom he shall gather these things. 7 tantum in imagine ambulat homo tantum frustra turbatur congregat et ignorat cui dimittat ea
8 And now what is my hope? is it not the Lord? and my substance is with thee. 8 nunc ergo quid expecto Domine praestolatio mea tu es
9 Deliver thou me from all my iniquities: thou hast made me a reproach to the fool. 9 ab omnibus iniquitatibus meis libera me obprobrium stulto ne ponas me
10 I was dumb, and I opened not my mouth, because thou hast done it. 10 obmutui non aperiam os meum quia tu fecisti
11 Remove thy scourges from me. The strength of thy hand hath made me faint in rebukes: 11 tolle a me plagas tuas
12 Thou hast corrected man for iniquity. And thou hast made his soul to waste away like a spider: surely in vain is any man disquieted. 12 a contentione manus tuae ego consumptus sum in increpationibus pro iniquitate corripuisti virum et posuisti quasi tineam desiderabilia eius verumtamen vanitas omnis homo semper
13 Hear my prayer, O Lord, and my supplication: give ear to my tears. Be no silent: for I am a stranger with thee, and a sojourner as all my fathers were. 13 audi orationem meam Domine et clamorem meum exaudi ad lacrimam meam ne obsurdescas quia advena ego sum apud te et peregrinus sicut omnes patres mei
14 O forgive me, that I may be refreshed, before I go hence, and be no more. 14 parce mihi ut rideam antequam vadam et non subsistam

Chapter 39

Expectans expectavi. Christ's coming, and redeeming mankind.

1 Unto the end, a psalm for David himself. 1 pro victoria David canticum
2 With expectation I have waited for the Lord, and he was attentive to me. 2 expectans expectavi Dominum et inclinatus est ad me
3 And he heard my prayers, and brought me out of the pit of misery and the mire of dregs. And he set my feet upon a rock, and directed my steps. 3 et audivit clamorem meum et eduxit me de lacu famoso de luto caeni et statuit super petram pedes meos stabilivit gressus meos
4 And he put a new canticle into my mouth, a song to our God. Many shall see, and shall fear: and they shall hope in the Lord. 4 et dedit in ore meo canticum novum laudem Deo nostro videbunt multi et timebunt et sperabunt in Domino
5 Blessed is the man whose trust is in the name of the Lord; and who hath not had regard to vanities, and lying follies. 5 beatus vir qui posuit Dominum confidentiam suam et non est aversus ad superbias pompasque mendacii
6 Thou hast multiplied thy wonderful works, O Lord my God: and in thy thoughts there is no one like to thee. I have declared and I have spoken they are multiplied above number. 6 multa fecisti tu Domine Deus meus mirabilia tua et cogitationes tuas pro nobis non invenio ordinem coram te si narrare voluero et numerare plura sunt quam ut narrari queant
7 Sacrifice and oblation thou didst not desire; but thou hast pierced ears for me. Burnt offering and sin offering thou didst not require: 7 victima et oblatione non indiges aures fodisti mihi holocaustum et pro peccato non petisti
8 Then said I, Behold I come. In the head of the book it is written of me 8 tunc dixi ecce venio in volumine libri scriptum est de me
9 That I should do thy will: O my God, I have desired it, and thy law in the midst of my heart. 9 ut facerem placitum tibi Deus meus volui et legem tuam in medio ventris mei
10 I have declared thy justice in a great church, lo, I will not restrain my lips: O Lord, thou knowest it. 10 adnuntiavi iustum in ecclesia multa ecce labia mea non prohibebo Domine tu nosti
11 I have not hid thy justice within my heart: I have declared thy truth and thy salvation. I have not concealed thy mercy and thy truth from a great council. 11 iustitiam tuam non abscondi in medio cordis mei fidem tuam et salutare tuum dixi non abscondi misericordiam tuam et veritatem tuam in ecclesia multa
12 Withhold not thou, O Lord, thy tender mercies from me: thy mercy and thy truth have always upheld me. 12 tu Domine non prohibebis misericordias tuas a me misericordia tua et veritas iugiter servabunt me
13 For evils without number have surrounded me; my iniquities have overtaken me, and I was not able to see. They are multiplied above the hairs of my head: and my heart hath forsaken me. 13 circumdederunt enim me mala quorum non est numerus conprehenderunt me iniquitates meae et non potui videre plures factae sunt quam capilli capitis mei et cor meum dereliquit me
14 Be pleased, O Lord, to deliver me. look down, O Lord, to help me. 14 placeat tibi Domine ut liberes me Domine ad adiuvandum me festina
15 Let them be confounded and ashamed together, that seek after my soul to take it away. Let them be turned backward and be ashamed that desire evils to me. 15 confundantur et revereantur simul quaerentes animam meam ut auferant eam convertantur retrorsum et confundantur qui volunt mala mihi
16 Let them immediately bear their confusion, that say to me: 'T is well, t' is well. 16 pereant post confusionem suam qui dicunt mihi va va
17 Let all that seek thee rejoice and be glad in thee: and let such as love thy salvation say always: The Lord be magnified. 17 gaudeant et laetentur in te qui quaerunt te dicant iugiter magnificetur Dominus qui diligunt salutare tuum
18 But I am a beggar and poor: the Lord is careful for me. Thou art my helper and my protector: O my God, be not slack. 18 ego autem sum egens et pauper Dominus sollicitus erit pro me auxilium meum et salutare meum tu Deus meus ne moreris

Chapter 40

Beatus qui intelligit. The happiness of him that shall believe in Christ; notwithstanding the humility and poverty in which he shall come: the malice of his enemies, especially of the traitor Judas.

1 Unto the end, a psalm for David himself. 1 pro victoria canticum David
2 Blessed is he that understandeth concerning the needy and the poor: the Lord will deliver him in the evil day. 2 beatus qui cogitat de paupere in die mala salvabit eum Dominus
3 The Lord preserve him and give him life, and make him blessed upon the earth: and deliver him not up to the will of his enemies. 3 Dominus custodiet eum et vivificabit eum et beatus erit in terra et non tradet eum animae inimicorum suorum
4 The Lord help him on his bed of sorrow: thou hast turned all his couch in his sickness. 4 Dominus confortabit eum in lecto infirmitatis totum stratum eius vertisti in aegrotatione sua
5 I said: O Lord, be thou merciful to me: heal my soul, for I have sinned against thee. 5 ego dixi Domine miserere mei sana animam meam quoniam peccavi tibi
6 My enemies have spoken evils against me: when shall he die and his name perish? 6 inimici mei loquentur malum mihi quando morietur et periet nomen eius
7 And if he came in to see me, he spoke vain things: his heart gathered together iniquity to itself. He went out and spoke to the same purpose. 7 et si venerit ut visitet vana loquetur cor eius congregabit iniquitatem sibi et egrediens foras detrahet
8 All my enemies whispered together against me: they devised evils to me. 8 simul adversum me murmurabant omnes odientes me contra cogitabant malum mihi
9 They determined against me an unjust word: shall he that sleepeth rise again no more? 9 verbum diabuli infundebant sibi qui dormivit non addet ut resurgat
10 For even the man of my peace, in whom I trusted, who ate my bread, hath greatly supplanted me. 10 sed et homo pacificus meus in quo habui fiduciam qui manducabat panem meum levavit contra me plantam
11 But thou, O Lord, have mercy on me, and raise my up again: and I will requite them. 11 tu autem Domine miserere mei et leva me ut reddam eis
12 By this I know, that thou hast had a good will for me: because my enemy shall not rejoice over me. 12 in hoc cognovi quod velis me quia non insultavit inimicus meus mihi
13 But thou hast upheld me by reason of my innocence: and hast established me in thy sight for ever. 13 ego autem in simplicitate mea adiutus sum a te et statues me ante faciem tuam in perpetuum
14 Blessed be the Lord the God of Israel from eternity to eternity. So be it. So be it. 14 benedictus Dominus Deus Israhel a saeculo et usque in saeculum amen amen

Chapter 41

Quemadmodum desiderat. The fervent desire of the just after God: hope in afflictions.

1 Unto the end, understanding for the sons of Core. 1 pro victoria doctissimi filiorum Core
2 As the hart panteth after the fountains of water; so my soul panteth after thee, O God. 2 sicut areola praeparata ad inrigationes aquarum sic anima mea praeparata est ad te Deus
3 My soul hath thirsted after the strong living God; when shall I come and appear before the face of God? 3 sitivit anima mea Deum fortem viventem quando veniam et parebo ante faciem tuam
4 My tears have been my bread day and night, whilst it is said to me daily: Where is thy God? 4 fuerunt mihi lacrimae meae panis per diem ac noctem cum diceretur mihi tota die ubi est Deus tuus
5 These things I remembered, and poured out my soul in me: for I shall go over into the place of the wonderful tabernacle, even to the house of God: With the voice of joy and praise; the noise of one feasting. 5 horum recordatus sum et effudi in me animam meam quia veniam ad umbraculum tacebo usque ad domum Dei in voce laudis et confessionis multitudinis festa celebrantis
6 Why art thou sad, O my soul? and why dost thou trouble me? Hope in God, for I will still give praise to him: the salvation of my countenance, 6 quare incurvaris anima mea et conturbas me expecta Dominum quia adhuc confitebor ei salutaribus vultus eius
7 And my God. My soul is troubled within my self: therefore will I remember thee from the land of Jordan and Hermoniim, from the little hill. 7 Deus meus in memet ipso anima mea incurvatur propterea recordabor tui de terra Iordanis et Hermoniim de monte minimo
8 Deep calleth on deep, at the noise of thy flood-gates. All thy heights and thy billows have passed over me. 8 abyssus abyssum vocat in voce cataractarum tuarum omnes gurgites tui et fluctus tui super me transierunt
9 In the daytime the Lord hath commanded his mercy; and a canticle to him in the night. With me is prayer to the God of my life. 9 per diem mandavit Dominus misericordiam suam et in nocte canticum eius mecum oratio Deo vitae meae
10 I will say to God: Thou art my support. Why hast thou forgotten me? and why go I mourning, whilst my enemy afflicteth me? 10 dicam Deo petra mea quare oblitus es mei quare tristis incedo adfligente inimico
11 Whilst my bones are broken, my enemies who trouble me have reproached me; Whilst they say to me day by day: Where is thy God? 11 cum me interficerent in ossibus meis exprobraverunt mihi hostes mei dicentes tota die ubi est Deus tuus
12 Why art thou cast down, O my soul? and why dost thou disquiet me? Hope thou in God, for I will still give praise to him: the salvation of my countenance, and my God. 12 quare incurvaris anima mea et conturbas me expecta Dominum quoniam adhuc confitebor ei salutibus vultus mei et Deo meo

Chapter 42

Judica me, Deus. The prophet aspireth after the temple and altar of God.

1 A psalm for David. Judge me, O God, and distinguish my cause from the nation that is not holy: deliver me from the unjust and deceitful man. 1 iudica me Deus et discerne causam meam a gente non sancta a viro doloso et iniquo salva me
2 For thou art God my strength: why hast thou cast me off? and why do I go sorrowful whilst the enemy afflicteth me? 2 tu enim Deus fortitudo mea quare proiecisti me quare tristis incedo adfligente inimico
3 Sent forth thy light and thy truth: they have conducted me, and brought me unto thy holy hill, and into thy tabernacles. 3 mitte lucem tuam et veritatem tuam ipsae ducent me et introducent ad montem sanctum tuum et ad tabernaculum tuum
4 And I will go in to the altar of God: to God who giveth joy to my youth. 4 et introibo ad altare tuum ad Deum laetitiae et exultationis meae et confitebor tibi in cithara Deus Deus meus
5 To thee, O God my God, I will give praise upon the harp: why art thou sad, O my soul? and why dost thou disquiet me? 5 quare incurvaris anima mea et quare conturbas me expecta Dominum quoniam adhuc confitebor ei salutibus vultus mei et Deo meo
6 Hope in God, for I will still give praise to him: the salvation of my countenance, and my God. .

Chapter 43

Deus auribus nostris. The church commemorates former favours, and present afflictions; under which she prays for succour.

1 Unto the end, for the sons of Core, to give understanding. 1 pro victoria filiorum Core eruditionis
2 We have heard, O God, with our ears: our fathers have declared to us, The work thou hast wrought in their days, and in the days of old. 2 Deus auribus nostris audivimus patres nostri narraverunt nobis opus quod operatus es in diebus eorum in diebus antiquis
3 Thy hand destroyed the Gentiles, and thou plantedst them: thou didst afflict the people and cast them out. 3 tu manu tua gentes delisti et plantasti eos adflixisti populos et emisisti eos
4 For they got not the possession of the land by their own sword: neither did their own arm save them. But thy right hand and thy arm, and the light of thy countenance: because thou wast pleased with them. 4 non enim in gladio suo possederunt terram neque brachium eorum salvavit eos sed dextera tua et brachium tuum et lux vultus tui quia conplacuisti tibi
5 Thou art thyself my king and my God, who commandest the saving of Jacob. 5 tu es rex meus Deus praecipe pro salutibus Iacob
6 Through thee we will push down our enemies with the horn: and through thy name we will despise them that rise up against us. 6 in te hostes nostros ventilabimus in nomine tuo conculcabimus adversarios nostros
7 For I will not trust in my bow: neither shall my sword save me. 7 non enim in arcu meo confidam neque gladius meus salvabit me
8 But thou hast saved us from them that afflict us: and hast put them to shame that hate us. 8 quia salvasti nos de hostibus nostris et eos qui oderant nos confudisti
9 In God shall we glory all the day long: and in thy name we will give praise for ever. 9 in Domino gaudebimus tota die et in nomine tuo in aeternum confitebimur semper
10 But now thou hast cast us off, and put us to shame: and thou , O God, wilt not go out with our armies. 10 verum tu proiecisti et confudisti nos et non egredieris in exercitibus nostris
11 Thou hast made us turn our back to our enemies: and they that hated us plundered for themselves. 11 vertisti terga nostra hosti et qui oderant nos diripuerunt nos
12 Thou hast given us up like sheep to be eaten: thou hast scattered us among the nations. 12 dedisti nos quasi gregem ad vorandum et in gentibus dispersisti nos
13 Thou hast sold thy people for no price: and there was no reckoning in the exchange of them. 13 vendidisti populum tuum sine pretio nec grandis fuit commutatio eorum
14 Thou hast made us a reproach to our neighbours, a scoff and derision to them that are round about us. 14 posuisti nos obprobrium vicinis nostris subsannationem et inrisum his qui erant in circuitu nostro
15 Thou hast made us a byword among the Gentiles: a shaking of the head among the people. 15 posuisti nos similitudinem in gentibus commotionem capitis in tribubus
16 All the day long my shame is before me: and the confusion of my face hath covered me, 16 tota die confusio mea contra me et ignominia faciei meae cooperuit me
17 At the voice of him that reproacheth and detracteth me: at the face of the enemy and persecutor. 17 a voce exprobrantis et blasphemantis a facie inimici et ultoris
18 All these things have come upon us, yet we have not forgotten thee: and we have not done wickedly in thy covenant. 18 omnia haec venerunt super nos et non sumus obliti tui nec mentiti fuimus in pacto tuo
19 And our heart hath not turned back: neither hast thou turned aside our steps from thy way. 19 non est conversum retro cor nostrum nec declinaverunt gressus nostri a semita tua
20 For thou hast humbled us in the place of affliction: and the shadow of death hath covered us. 20 quoniam deiecisti nos in loco draconum et operuisti nos umbra mortis
21 If we have forgotten the name of our God, and if we have spread forth our hands to a strange god: 21 si obliti sumus nominis Dei nostri et expandimus manus nostras ad deum alienum
22 Shall not God search out these things: for he knoweth the secrets of the heart. Because for thy sake we are killed all the day long: we are counted as sheep for the slaughter. 22 numquid non Deus investigabit istud ipse enim novit cogitationes cordis quoniam propter te mortificati sumus tota die reputati sumus ut grex occisionis
23 Arise, why sleepest thou, O Lord? arise, and cast us not off to the end. 23 consurge quare dormitas Domine evigila quare proicis nos in sempiternum
24 Why turnest thou thy face away? and forgettest our want and our trouble? 24 quare faciem tuam abscondis oblivisceris adflictiones et angustias nostras
25 For our soul is humbled down to the dust: our belly cleaveth to the earth. 25 quoniam incurvata est in pulvere anima nostra adhesit terrae venter noster
26 Arise, O Lord, help us and redeem us for thy name's sake. 26 surge auxiliare nobis et redime nos propter misericordiam tuam

Chapter 44

Eructavit cor meum. The excellence of Christ's kingdom, and the endowments of his church.

1 Unto the end, for them that shall be changed, for the sons of Core, for understanding. A canticle for the Beloved. 1 victori pro liliis filiorum Core eruditionis canticum amantissimi
2 My heart hath uttered a good word: I speak my works to the king: My tongue is the pen of a scrivener that writeth swiftly. 2 eructavit cor meum verbum bonum dico ego opera mea regi lingua mea stilus scribae velocis
3 Thou art beautiful above the sons of men: grace is poured abroad in thy lips; therefore hath God blessed thee for ever. 3 decore pulchrior es filiis hominum effusa est gratia in labiis tuis propterea benedixit tibi Deus in aeternum
4 Gird thy sword upon thy thigh, O thou most mighty. 4 accingere gladio tuo super femur fortissime
5 With thy comeliness and thy beauty set out, proceed prosperously, and reign. Because of truth and meekness and justice: and thy right hand shall conduct thee wonderfully. 5 gloria tua et decore tuo decore tuo prospere ascende propter veritatem et mansuetudinem iustitiae et docebit te terribilia dextera tua
6 Thy arrows are sharp: under thee shall people fall, into the hearts of the king's enemies. 6 sagittae tuae acutae populi sub te cadent in corde inimicorum regis
7 Thy throne, O God, is forever and ever: the sceptre of thy kingdom is a sceptre of uprightness. 7 thronus tuus Deus in saeculum et in aeternum sceptrum aequitatis sceptrum regni tui
8 Thou hast loved justice, and hated iniquity: therefore God, thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows. 8 dilexisti iustitiam et odisti iniquitatem propterea unxit te Deus Deus tuus oleo exultationis prae participibus tuis
9 Myrrh and stacte and cassia perfume thy garments, from the ivory houses: out of which 9 zmyrna et stacte et cassia in cunctis vestimentis tuis de domibus eburneis quibus laetificaverunt te
10 The daughters of kings have delighted thee in thy glory. The queen stood on thy right hand, in gilded clothing; surrounded with variety. 10 filiae regum in honore tuo stetit coniux in dextera tua in diademate aureo
11 Hearken, O daughter, and see, and incline thy ear: and forget thy people and thy father's house. 11 audi filia et vide et inclina aurem tuam et obliviscere populi tui et domus patris tui
12 And the king shall greatly desire thy beauty; for he is the Lord thy God, and him they shall adore. 12 et concupiscet rex decorem tuum quia ipse est dominus tuus et adora eum
13 And the daughters of Tyre with gifts, yea, all the rich among the people, shall entreat thy countenance. 13 et o filia fortissimi in muneribus faciem tuam deprecabuntur divites populi
14 All the glory of the king's daughter is within in golden borders, 14 omnis gloria filiae regis intrinsecus fasceis aureis vestita est
15 Clothed round about with varieties. After her shall virgins be brought to the king: her neighbours shall be brought to thee. 15 in scutulatis ducetur ad regem virgines sequentur eam amicae eius ducentur illuc
16 They shall be brought with gladness and rejoicing: they shall be brought into the temple of the king. 16 ducentur in laetitiis et exultatione ingredientur thalamum regis
17 Instead of thy fathers, sons are born to thee: thou shalt make them princes over all the earth. 17 pro patribus tuis erunt filii tibi pones eos principes in universa terra
18 They shall remember thy name throughout all generations. Therefore shall people praise thee for ever; yea, for ever and ever. 18 recordabor nominis tui in omni generatione et generatione propterea populi confitebuntur tibi in saeculum et in aeternum

Chapter 45

Deus noster refugium. The church in persecution trusteth in the protection of God.

1 Unto the end, for the sons of Core, for the hidden. 1 victori filiorum Core pro iuventutibus canticum
2 Our God is our refuge and strength: a helper in troubles, which have found us exceedingly. 2 Deus nostra spes et fortitudo auxilium in tribulationibus inventus es validum
3 Therefore we will not fear, when the earth shall be troubled; and the mountains shall be removed into the heart of the sea. 3 ideo non timebimus cum fuerit translata terra et concussi montes in corde maris
4 Their waters roared and were troubled: the mountains were troubled with his strength. 4 sonantibus et intumescentibus gurgitibus eius et agitatis montibus in potentia eius semper
5 The stream of the river maketh the city of God joyful: the most High hath sanctified his own tabernacle. 5 fluminis divisiones laetificant civitatem Dei sanctum tabernaculum Altissimi
6 God is in the midst thereof, it shall not be moved: God will help it in the morning early. 6 Dominus in medio eius non commovebitur auxiliabitur ei Deus in ipso ortu matutino
7 Nations were troubled, and kingdoms were bowed down: he uttered his voice, the earth trembled. 7 conturbatae sunt gentes concussa sunt regna dedit vocem suam prostrata est terra
8 The Lord of armies is with us: the God of Jacob is our protector. 8 Dominus exercituum nobiscum protector noster Deus Iacob semper
9 Come and behold ye the works of the Lord: what wonders he hath done upon earth, 9 venite et videte opera Domini quantas posuerit solitudines in terra
10 Making wars to cease even to the end of the earth. He shall destroy the bow, and break the weapons: and the shield he shall burn in the fire. 10 conpescuit bella usque ad extremum terrae arcum confringet et concidet hastam plaustra conburet igni
11 Be still and see that I am God; I will be exalted among the nations, and I will be exalted in the earth. 11 cessate et cognoscite quoniam ego sum Deus exaltabor in gentibus exaltabor in terra
12 The Lord of armies is with us: the God of Jacob is our protector. 12 Dominus exercituum nobiscum fortitudo nostra Deus Iacob semper

Chapter 46

Omnes gentes, plaudite. The Gentiles are invited to praise God for the establishment of the kingdom of Christ.

1 Unto the end, for the sons of Core. 1 victori filiorum Core canticum
2 O clap your hands, all ye nations: shout unto God with the voice of joy, 2 omnes populi plaudite manibus iubilate Deo in voce laudis
3 For the Lord is high, terrible: a great king over all the earth. 3 quoniam Dominus altissimus terribilis rex magnus super omnem terram
4 He hath subdued the people under us; and the nations under our feet. 4 congregavit populos subter nos et tribus sub pedibus nostris
5 He hath chosen for us his inheritance, the beauty of Jacob which he hath love. 5 elegit nobis hereditatem nostram gloriam Iacob quam dilexit semper
6 God is ascended with jubilee, and the Lord with the sound of trumpet. 6 ascendit Deus in iubilo Deus in voce bucinae
7 Sing praises to our God, sing ye: sing praises to our king, sing ye. 7 canite Deo canite canite regi nostro canite
8 For God is the king of all the earth: sing ye wisely. 8 quia rex universae terrae Deus canite erudite
9 God shall reign over the nations: God sitteth on his holy throne. 9 regnavit Deus super gentes Deus sedet super thronum sanctum suum
10 The princes of the people are gathered together, with the God of Abraham: for the strong gods of the earth are exceedingly exalted. 10 principes populorum congregati sunt populus Dei Abraham quoniam Dei scuta terrae vehementer elevata sunt

Chapter 47

Magnus Dominus. God is greatly to be praised for the establishment of his church.

1 A psalm of a canticle, for the sons of Core, on the second day of the week. 1 canticum psalmi filiorum Core
2 Great is the Lord, and exceedingly to be praised in the city of our God, in his holy mountain. 2 magnus Dominus et laudabilis nimis in civitate Dei nostri in monte sancto suo
3 With the joy of the whole earth is mount Sion founded, on the sides of the north, the city of the great king. 3 specioso germini gaudio universae terrae monti Sion lateribus aquilonis civitatulae regis magni
4 In her houses shall God be known, when he shall protect her. 4 Deus in domibus eius agnitus est in auxiliando
5 For behold the kings of the earth assembled themselves: they gathered together. 5 quia ecce reges congregati sunt venerunt simul
6 So they saw, and they wondered, they were troubled, they were moved: 6 ipsi videntes sic obstipuerunt conturbati sunt admirati sunt
7 Trembling took hold of them. There were pains as of a woman in labour. 7 horror possedit eos ibi dolor quasi parturientis
8 With a vehement wind thou shalt break in pieces the ships of Tharsis. 8 in vento uredinis confringes naves maris
9 As we have heard, so have we seen, in the city of the Lord of hosts, in the city of our God: God hath founded it for ever. 9 sicut audivimus ita vidimus in civitate Dei exercituum in civitate Dei nostri Deus fundavit eam usque in aeternum semper
10 We have received thy mercy, O God, in the midst of thy temple. 10 aestimavimus Deus misericordiam tuam in medio templi tui
11 According to thy name, O God, so also is thy praise unto the ends of the earth: thy right hand is full of justice. 11 secundum nomen tuum Deus sic laus tua usque ad extremum terrae iustitia repleta est dextera tua
12 Let mount Sion rejoice, and the daughters of Juda be glad; because of thy judgments, O Lord. 12 laetetur mons Sion exultent filiae Iudae propter iudicia tua
13 Surround Sion, and encompass her: tell lye in her towers. 13 circumdate Sion et circumite eam numerate turres eius
14 Set your hearts on her strength; and distribute her houses, that ye may relate it in another generation. 14 ponite cor vestrum in moenibus separate palatia eius ut narretis in generatione novissima
15 For this is God, our God unto eternity, and for ever and ever: he shall rule us for evermore. 15 quia ipse Deus Deus noster in saeculum et in perpetuum ipse erit dux noster in morte

Chapter 48

Audite haec, omnes gentes. The folly of worldlings, who live on in sin, without thinking of death or hell.

1 Unto the end, a psalm for the sons of Core. 1 victori filiorum Core canticum
2 Hear these things, all ye nations: give ear, all ye inhabitants of the world. 2 audite hoc omnes populi auribus percipite universi habitatores occidentis
3 All you that are earthborn, and you sons of men: both rich and poor together. 3 tam filii Adam quam filii singulorum simul dives et pauper
4 My mouth shall speak wisdom: and the meditation of my heart understanding. 4 os meum loquitur sapientias et meditatio cordis mei prudentias
5 I will incline my ear to a parable; I will open my proposition on the psaltery. 5 inclino ad parabulam aurem meam aperiam in cithara enigma meum
6 Why shall I fear in the evil day? the iniquity of my heel shall encompass me. 6 quare timebo in diebus mali iniquitas calcanei mei circumdabit me
7 They that trust in their own strength, and glory in the multitude of their riches, 7 qui fiduciam habent in fortitudine sua et in multitudine divitiarum suarum superbiunt
8 No brother can redeem, nor shall man redeem: he shall not give to God his ransom, 8 fratrem redimens non redimet vir nec dabit Deo propitiationem pro eo
9 Nor the price of the redemption of his soul: and shall labour for ever, 9 neque pretium redemptionis animae eorum sed quiescet in saeculo
10 And shall still live unto the end. 10 et vivet ultra in sempiternum
11 He shall not see destruction, when he shall see the wise dying: the senseless and the fool shall perish together: And they shall leave their riches to strangers: 11 et non videbit interitum cum viderit sapientes morientes simul insipiens et indoctus peribunt et derelinquent alienis divitias suas
12 And their sepulchres shall be their houses for ever. Their dwelling places to all generations: they have called their lands by their names. 12 interiora sua domus suas in saeculo tabernacula sua in generatione et generatione vocaverunt nominibus suis terras suas
13 And man when he was in honour did not understand; he is compared to senseless beasts, and is become like to them. 13 et homo in honore non commorabitur adsimilatus est iumentis et exaequatus est
14 This way of theirs is a stumblingblock to them: and afterwards they shall delight in their mouth. 14 haec est via insipientiae eorum et post eos iuxta os eorum current semper
15 They are laid in hell like sheep: death shall feed upon them. And the just shall have dominion over them in the morning; and their help shall decay in hell from their glory. 15 quasi grex in inferno positi sunt mors pascet eos et subicient eos recti in matutino et figura eorum conteretur in inferno post habitaculum suum
16 But God will redeem my soul from the hand of hell, when he shall receive me. 16 verumtamen Deus redimet animam meam de manu inferi cum adsumpserit me semper
17 Be not thou afraid, when a man shall be made rick, and when the glory of his house shall be increased. 17 noli timere cum ditatus fuerit vir cum multiplicata fuerit gloria domus eius
18 For when he shall die he shall take nothing away; nor shall his glory descend with him. 18 neque enim moriens tollet omnia nec descendet post eum gloria eius
19 For in his lifetime his soul will be blessed: and he will praise thee when thou shalt do well to him. 19 quia animae suae in vita sua benedicet laudabunt inquient te cum benefeceris tibi
20 He shall go in to the generations of his fathers: and he shall never see light. 20 intrabit usque ad generationes patrum suorum usque ad finem non videbunt lucem
21 Man when he was in honour did not understand: he hath been compared to senseless beasts, and made like to them. 21 homo cum in honore esset non intellexit conparavit se iumentis et silebitur

Chapter 49

Deus deorum. The coming of Christ: who prefers virtue and inward purity before the blood of victims.

1 A psalm for Asaph. The God of gods, the Lord hath spoken: and he hath called the earth. From the rising of the sun, to the going down thereof: 1 canticum Asaph fortis Deus Dominus locutus est et vocavit terram ab ortu solis usque ad occasum eius
2 Out of Sion the loveliness of his beauty. 2 de Sion perfecta decore Deus apparuit
3 God shall come manifestly: our God shall come, and shall not keep silence. A fire shall burn before him: and a mighty tempest shall be round about him. 3 veniet Deus noster et non tacebit ignis coram eo vorabit et in circuitu eius tempestas valida
4 He shall call heaven from above, and the earth, to judge his people. 4 vocabit caelum desursum et terram ut iudicet populum suum
5 Gather ye together his saints to him: who set his covenant before sacrifices. 5 congregate mihi sanctos meos qui feriunt pactum meum in sacrificio
6 And the heavens shall declare his justice: for God is judge. 6 et adnuntiabunt caeli iustitiam eius quia Deus iudex est semper
7 Hear, O my people, and I will speak: O Israel, and I will testify to thee: I am God, thy God. 7 audi popule meus et loquar Israhel et contestabor te Deus Deus tuus ego sum
8 I will not reprove thee for thy sacrifices: and thy burnt offerings are always in my sight. 8 non propter victimas tuas arguam te et holocaustomata tua coram me sunt semper
9 I will not take calves out of thy house: nor he goats out of thy flocks. 9 non accipiam de domo tua vitulum neque de gregibus tuis hircos
10 For all the beasts of the woods are mine: the cattle on the hills, and the oxen. 10 mea sunt enim omnia animalia silvarum pecudes in montibus milium
11 I know all the fowls of the air: and with me is the beauty of the field. 11 scio omnes aves montium et universitas agri mecum est
12 If I should be hungry, I would not tell thee: for the world is mine, and the fulness thereof. 12 si esuriero non dicam tibi meus est enim orbis et plenitudo eius
13 Shall I eat the flesh of bullocks? or shall I drink the blood of goats? 13 numquid comedam carnem taurorum aut sanguinem hircorum bibam
14 Offer to God the sacrifice of praise: and pay thy vows to the most High. 14 immola Deo laudem et redde Altissimo vota tua
15 And call upon me in the day of trouble: I will deliver thee, and thou shalt glorify me. 15 et invoca me in die tribulationis liberabo te et glorificabis me
16 But to the sinner God hath said: Why dost thou declare my justices, and take my covenant in thy mouth? 16 impio autem dixit Deus quid tibi est cum narratione praeceptorum meorum et ut adsumas pactum meum in ore tuo
17 Seeing thou hast hated discipline: and hast cast my words behind thee. 17 qui odisti disciplinam et proiecisti verba mea post te
18 If thou didst see a thief thou didst run with him: and with adulterers thou hast been a partaker. 18 si videbas furem consentiebas ei et cum adulteris erat pars tua
19 Thy mouth hath abounded with evil, and thy tongue framed deceits. 19 os tuum dimisisti ad malitiam et lingua tua concinnavit dolum
20 Sitting thou didst speak against thy brother, and didst lay a scandal against thy mother's son: 20 sedens adversum fratrem tuum loquebaris et adversum filium matris tuae fabricabaris obprobrium
21 These things hast thou done, and I was silent. Thou thoughtest unjustly that I should be like to thee: but I will reprove thee, and set before thy face. 21 haec fecisti et tacui existimasti futurum me similem tui arguam te et proponam te ante oculos tuos
22 Understand these things, you that forget God; lest he snatch you away, and there be none to deliver you. 22 intellegite hoc qui obliviscimini Deum ne forte capiam et non sit qui liberet
23 The sacrifice of praise shall glorify me: and there is the way by which I will shew him the salvation of God. 23 qui immolat confessionem glorificat me et qui ordinate ambulat ostendam ei salutare Dei

Chapter 50

Miserere. The repentance and confession of David after his sin. The fourth penitential psalm.

1 Unto the end, a psalm of David, 1 victori canticum David
2 When Nathan the prophet came to him, after he had sinned with Bethsabee. [2 Kings 12.] 2 cum venisset ad eum Nathan propheta quando ingressus est ad Bethsabee
3 Have mercy on me, O God, according to thy great mercy. And according to the multitude of thy tender mercies blot out my iniquity. 3 miserere mei Deus secundum misericordiam tuam iuxta multitudinem miserationum tuarum dele iniquitates meas
4 Wash me yet more from my iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin. 4 multum lava me ab iniquitate mea et a peccato meo munda me
5 For I know my iniquity, and my sin is always before me. 5 quoniam iniquitates meas ego novi et peccatum meum contra me est semper
6 To thee only have I sinned, and have done evil before thee: that thou mayst be justified in thy words, and mayst overcome when thou art judged. 6 tibi soli peccavi et malum coram te feci ut iustificeris in sermonibus tuis et vincas cum iudicaveris
7 For behold I was conceived in iniquities; and in sins did my mother conceive me. 7 ecce in iniquitate conceptus sum et in peccato peperit me mater mea
8 For behold thou hast loved truth: the uncertain and hidden things of thy wisdom thou hast made manifest to me. 8 ecce enim veritatem diligis absconditum et arcanum sapientiae manifestasti mihi
9 Thou shalt sprinkle me with hyssop, and I shall be cleansed: thou shalt wash me, and I shall be made whiter than snow. 9 asparges me hysopo et mundabor lavabis me et super nivem dealbabor
10 To my hearing thou shalt give joy and gladness: and the bones that have been humbled shall rejoice. 10 auditum mihi facies gaudium et laetitiam ut exultent ossa quae confregisti
11 Turn away thy face from my sins, and blot out all my iniquities. 11 absconde faciem tuam a peccatis meis et omnes iniquitates meas dele
12 Create a clean heart in me, O God: and renew a right spirit within my bowels. 12 cor mundum crea mihi Deus et spiritum stabilem renova in visceribus meis
13 Cast me not away from thy face; and take not thy holy spirit from me. 13 ne proicias me a facie tua et spiritum sanctum tuum ne auferas a me
14 Restore unto me the joy of thy salvation, and strengthen me with a perfect spirit. 14 redde mihi laetitiam Iesu tui et spiritu potenti confirma me
15 I will teach the unjust thy ways: and the wicked shall be converted to thee. 15 docebo iniquos vias tuas et peccatores ad te revertentur
16 Deliver me from blood, O God, thou God of my salvation: and my tongue shall extol thy justice. 16 libera me de sanguinibus Deus Deus salutis meae laudabit lingua mea iustitiam tuam
17 O Lord, thou wilt open my lips: and my mouth shall declare thy praise. 17 Domine labia mea aperies et os meum adnuntiabit laudem tuam
18 For if thou hadst desired sacrifice, I would indeed have given it: with burnt offerings thou wilt not be delighted. 18 non enim vis ut victimam feriam nec holocaustum tibi placet
19 A sacrifice to God is an afflicted spirit: a contrite and humbled heart, O God, thou wilt not despise. 19 sacrificium Dei spiritus contribulatus cor contritum et humiliatum Deus non dispicies
20 Deal favourably, O Lord, in thy good will with Sion; that the walls of Jerusalem may be built up. 20 benefac Domine in voluntate tua Sion et aedificentur muri Hierusalem
21 Then shalt thou accept the sacrifice of justice, oblations and whole burnt offerings: then shall they lay calves upon thy altar. 21 tunc suscipies sacrificium iustitiae oblationes et holocausta tunc inponent super altare tuum vitulos

Chapter 51

Quid gloriaris. David condemneth the wickedness of Doeg, and foretelleth his destruction.

1 Unto the end, understanding for David, 1 victori ab erudito David
2 When Doeg the Edomite came and told Saul: David went to the house of Achimelech. 2 cum venisset Doec Idumeus et adnuntiasset Saul dicens ei venit David in domum Achimelech
3 Why dost thou glory in malice, thou that art mighty in iniquity? 3 quid gloriaris in malitia potens misericordia Dei tota est die
4 All the day long thy tongue hath devised injustice: as a sharp razor, thou hast wrought deceit. 4 insidias cogitat lingua tua quasi novacula acuta faciens dolum
5 Thou hast loved malice more than goodness: and iniquity rather than to speak righteousness. 5 dilexisti malum magis quam bonum mendacium magis quam loqui iustitiam semper
6 Thou hast loved all the words of ruin, O deceitful tongue. 6 dilexisti omnia verba ad devorandum lingua dolosa
7 Therefore will God destroy thee for ever: he will pluck thee out, and remove thee from thy dwelling place: and thy root out of the land of the living. 7 sed Deus destruet te in sempiternum terrebit et evellet te de tabernaculo et eradicabit te de terra viventium semper
8 The just shall see and fear, and shall laugh at him, and say: 8 videbunt iusti et timebunt et super eum ridebunt
9 Behold the man that made not God his helper: But trusted in the abundance of his riches: and prevailed in his vanity. 9 ecce vir qui non posuit Deum fortitudinem suam sed speravit in multitudine divitiarum suarum confortatus est in insidiis suis
10 But I, as a fruitful olive tree in the house of God, have hoped in the mercy of God for ever, yea for ever and ever. 10 ego sicut oliva virens in domo Dei speravi in misericordia Dei in saeculum sempiternum
11 I will praise thee for ever, because thou hast done it: and I will wait on thy name, for it is good in the sight of thy saints. 11 confitebor tibi in saeculo quoniam fecisti et expectabo nomen tuum quoniam bonum in conspectu sanctorum tuorum

Chapter 52

Dixit insipiens. The general corruption of man before the coming of Christ.

1 Unto the end, for Maeleth, understandings to David. The fool said in his heart: There is no God. 1 victori per chorum eruditi David dixit stultus in corde suo non est Deus
2 They are corrupted, and become abominable in iniquities: there is none that doth good. 2 corrupti sunt et abominabiles facti sunt in iniquitate non est qui faciat bonum
3 God looked down from heaven on the children of men: to see if there were any that did understand, or did seek God. 3 Deus de caelo prospexit super filios hominum ut videret si esset intellegens requirens Deum
4 All have gone aside, they are become unprofitable together, there is none that doth good, no not one. 4 omnes aversi sunt pariter adheserunt non est qui faciat bonum non est usque ad unum
5 Shall not all the workers of iniquity know, who eat up my people as they eat bread? 5 numquid non cognoverunt qui operantur iniquitatem qui comedunt populum meum ut cibum panis
6 They have not called upon God: there have they trembled for fear, where there was no fear. For God hath scattered the bones of them that please men: they have been confounded, because God hath despised them. 6 Deum non invocaverunt ibi timuerunt timore ubi non est timor quoniam Deus dispersit ossa circumdantium te confunderis quia Deus proiecit eos
7 Who will give out of Sion the salvation of Israel? when God shall bring back the captivity of his people, Jacob shall rejoice, and Israel shall be glad. 7 quis dabit ex Sion salutare Israhel cum reduxerit Deus captivitatem populi sui exultabit Iacob laetabitur Israhel

Chapter 53

Deus, in nomine tuo. A prayer for help in distress.

1 Unto the end, in verses, understanding for David. 1 victori in psalmis eruditi David
2 When the en of Ziph had come and said to Saul: Is not David hidden with us? [1 Kings 23.19] 2 quando venerunt Ziphei et dixerunt Saul nonne David absconditus est apud nos
3 Save me, O God, by thy name, and judge me in thy strength. 3 Deus in nomine tuo salva me et in fortitudine tua ulciscere me
4 O God, hear my prayer: give ear to the words of my mouth. 4 Deus exaudi orationem meam auribus percipe verba oris mei
5 For strangers have risen up against me; and the mighty have sought after my soul: and they have not set God before their eyes. 5 quia alieni insurrexerunt adversus me et fortes quaesierunt animam meam et non posuerunt Deum in conspectu suo semper
6 For behold God is my helper: and the Lord is the protector of my soul. 6 ecce Deus auxiliatur mihi Dominus sustentans animam meam
7 Turn back the evils upon my enemies; and cut them off in thy truth. 7 reddet malum insidiatoribus meis in veritate tua disperde eos
8 I will freely sacrifice to thee, and will give praise, O God, to thy name: because it is good: 8 voluntarie sacrificabo tibi confitebor nomini tuo Domine quoniam bonum est
9 For thou hast delivered me out of all trouble: and my eye hath looked down upon my enemies. 9 quoniam ex omni tribulatione liberavit me et inimicos meos dispexit oculus meus

Chapter 54

Exaudi, Deus. A prayer of a just man under persecution from the wicked. It agrees to Christ persecuted by the Jews, and betrayed by Judas.

1 Unto the end, in verses, understanding for David. 1 victori in psalmis eruditi David
2 Hear, O God, my prayer, and despise not my supplication: 2 exaudi Deus orationem meam et ne dispicias deprecationem meam
3 Be attentive to me and hear me. I am grieved in my exercise; and am troubled, 3 adtende mihi et exaudi me humiliatus sum in meditatione mea et conturbatus
4 At the voice of the enemy, and at the tribulation of the sinner. For they have cast iniquities upon me: and in wrath they were troublesome to me. 4 a voce inimici a facie persequentis impii quoniam proiecerunt super me iniquitatem et in furore adversabantur mihi
5 My heart is troubled within me: and the fear of death is fallen upon me. 5 cor meum doluit in vitalibus meis et terrores mortis ceciderunt super me
6 Fear and trembling are come upon me: and darkness hath covered me. 6 timor et tremor venit super me et operuit me caligo
7 And I said: Who will give me wings like a dove, and I will fly and be at rest? 7 et dixi quis dabit mihi pinnas columbae ut volem et requiescam
8 Lo, I have gone far off flying away; and I abode in the wilderness. 8 ut procul abeam et commorer in deserto semper
9 I waited for him that hath saved me from pusillanimity of spirit, and a storm. 9 festinabo ut salver ab spiritu tempestatis et turbinis
10 Cast down, O Lord, and divide their tongues; for I have seen iniquity and contradiction in the city. 10 praecipita Domine divide linguas eorum quoniam vidi iniquitatem et contradictionem in civitate
11 Day and night shall iniquity surround it upon its walls: and in the midst thereof are labour, 11 die et nocte circumeuntes muros eius scelus et dolorem in medio eius
12 And injustice. And usury and deceit have not departed from its streets. 12 insidiae in vitalibus eius et non recedet de plateis eius damnum et fraudulentia
13 For if my enemy had reviled me, I would verily have borne with it. And if he that hated me had spoken great things against me, I would perhaps have hidden my self from him. 13 non enim inimicus exprobravit mihi ut sustineam neque is qui me oderat super me magnificatus est ut abscondar ab eo
14 But thou a man of one mind, my guide, and my familiar, 14 sed tu homo unianimis meus dux meus et notus meus
15 Who didst take sweetmeats together with me: in the house of God we walked with consent. 15 qui simul habuimus dulce secretum in domo Dei ambulavimus in terrore
16 Let death come upon them, and let them go down alive into hell. For there is wickedness in their dwellings: in the midst of them. 16 veniat mors super eos descendant in infernum viventes quia nequitiae in congregatione eorum et in medio eorum
17 But I have cried to God: and the Lord will save me. 17 ego ad Deum clamabo et Dominus salvabit me
18 Evening and morning, and at noon I will speak and declare: and he shall hear my voice. 18 vespere et mane et meridie eloquar et resonabo et exaudiet vocem meam
19 He shall redeem my soul in peace from them that draw near to me: for among many they were with me. 19 redimet in pace animam meam ab adpropinquantibus mihi multi enim fuerunt adversum me
20 God shall hear, and the Eternal shall humble them. For there is no change with them, and they have not feared God: 20 exaudiet Deus et humiliabit eos qui iudex est ab initio semper non enim mutantur neque timent Deum
21 He hath stretched forth his hand to repay. They have defiled his covenant, 21 extendit manum suam ad pacifica sua contaminabit pactum suum
22 They are divided by the wrath of his countenance, and his heart hath drawn near. His words are smoother than oil, and the same are darts. 22 nitidius butyro os eius pugnat autem cor illius molliores sermones eius oleo cum sint lanceae
23 Cast thy care upon the Lord, and he shall sustain thee: he shall not suffer the just to waver for ever. 23 proice super Dominum caritatem tuam et ipse enutriet te non dabit in aeternum fluctuationem iusto
