24 But thou, O God, shalt bring them down into the pit of destruction. Bloody and deceitful men shall not live out half their days; but I will trust in thee, O Lord. 24 tu autem Deus deduces eos in puteum interitus viri sanguinum et dolosi non dimidiabunt dies suos ego autem fiduciam habeo tui

Chapter 55

Miserere mei, Deus. A prayer of David in danger and distress.

1 Unto the end, for a people that is removed at a distance form the sanctuary: for David, for an inscription of a title (or pillar) when the Philistines held him in Geth. 1 victori pro columba muta eo quod procul abierit David humilis et simplex quando tenuerunt eum Palestini in Geth
2 Have mercy on me, O God, for man hath trodden me under foot; all the day long he hath afflicted me fighting against me. 2 miserere mei Deus quoniam conculcavit me homo tota die pugnans tribulavit me
3 My enemies have trodden on me all the day long; for they are many that make war against me. 3 conculcaverunt me insidiatores mei tota die multi enim qui pugnant contra me Altissime
4 From the height of the day I shall fear: but I will trust in thee. 4 quacumque die territus fuero ego in te confidam
5 In God I will praise my words, in God I have put my trust: I will not fear what flesh can do against me. 5 in Deo laudavi verbum in Deo speravi non timebo quid faciat caro mihi
6 All the day long they detested my words: all their thoughts were against me unto evil. 6 tota die sermonibus me adfligebant contra me omnes cogitationes eorum in malum
7 They will dwell and hide themselves: they will watch my heel. As they have waited for my soul, 7 congregabuntur abscondite plantas meas observabunt expectantes animam meam
8 For nothing shalt thou save them: in thy anger thou shalt break the people in pieces. O God, 8 quia nullus est salvus in eis in furore populos detrahet Deus
9 I have declared to thee my life: thou hast set me tears in thy sight, As also in thy promise. 9 secretiora mea numerasti pone lacrimam meam in conspectu tuo sed non in narratione tua
10 Then shall my enemies be turned back. In what day soever I shall call upon thee, behold I know thou art my God. 10 tunc convertentur inimici mei retrorsum in quacumque die invocavero hoc scio quia Deus meus es
11 In God will I praise the word, in the Lord will I praise his speech. In God have I hoped, I will not fear what man can do to me. 11 in Deo laudabo verbum in Domino praedicabo sermonem in Deo speravi non timebo quid faciat homo mihi
12 In me, O God, are vows to thee, which I will pay, praises to thee: 12 in me sunt Deus vota tua reddam gratiarum actiones tibi
13 Because thou hast delivered my soul from death, my feet from falling: that I may please in the sight of God, in the light of the living. 13 quia liberasti animam meam de morte et pedes meos de lapsu ut ambulem coram Deo in luce viventium

Chapter 56

Miserere mei, Deus. The prophet prays in his affliction, and praises God for his delivery.

1 Unto the end, destroy not, for David, for an inscription of a title, when he fled from Saul into the cave. [1 Kings 24.] 1 pro victoria ut non disperdas David humilem et simplicem quando fugit a facie Saul in spelunca
2 Have mercy on me, O God, have mercy on me: for my soul trusteth in thee. And in the shadow of thy wings will I hope, until iniquity pass away. 2 miserere mei Deus miserere mei quoniam in te sperat anima mea in umbra alarum tuarum sperabo donec transeant insidiae
3 I will cry to God the most high; to God who hath done good to me. 3 invocabo Deum altissimum Deum ultorem meum
4 He hath sent from heaven and delivered me: he hath made them a reproach that trod upon me. God hath sent his mercy and his truth, 4 mittet de caelo et salvabit me exprobrabit conculcantibus me semper mittet Deus misericordiam suam et veritatem suam
5 And he hath delivered my soul from the midst of the young lions. I slept troubled. The sons of men, whose teeth are weapons and arrows, and their tongue a sharp sword. 5 anima mea in medio leonum dormivit ferocientium filii hominum dentes eorum lancea et sagittae et lingua eorum gladius acutus
6 Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens, and thy glory above all the earth. 6 exaltare super caelos Deus in omni terra gloria tua
7 They prepared a snare for my feet; and they bowed down my soul. They dug a pit before my face, and they are fallen into it. 7 rete paraverunt gressibus meis ad incurvandam animam meam foderunt ante me foveam ceciderunt in medium eius semper
8 My heart is ready, O God, my heart is ready: I will sing, and rehearse a psalm. 8 paratum cor meum Deus paratum cor meum cantabo et psallam
9 Arise, O my glory, arise psaltery and harp: I will arise early. 9 surge gloria mea surge psalterium et cithara surgam mane
10 I will give praise to thee, O Lord, among the people: I will sing a psalm to thee among the nations. 10 confitebor tibi in populis Domine cantabo tibi in gentibus
11 For thy mercy is magnified even to the heavens: and thy truth unto the clouds. 11 quia magna usque ad caelos misericordia tua et usque ad nubes veritas tua
12 Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: and thy glory above all the earth. 12 exaltare super caelos Deus in omni terra gloria tua

Chapter 57

Si vere utique. David reproveth the wicked, and foretelleth their punishment.

1 Unto the end, destroy not, for David, for an inscription of a title. 1 victori ut non disperdas David humilem et simplicem
2 If in very deed ye speak justice: judge right things, ye sons of men. 2 si vere utique iustitiam loquimini recta iudicate filii hominum
3 For in your heart you work iniquity: your hands forge injustice in the earth. 3 etenim in corde iniquitates operamini in terra iniquitatis manus vestras adpendite
4 The wicked are alienated from the womb; they have gone astray from the womb: they have spoken false things. 4 alienati sunt peccatores a vulva erraverunt ab utero loquentes mendacium
5 Their madness is according to the likeness of a serpent: like the deaf asp that stoppeth her ears: 5 furor eorum sicut furor serpentis sicut reguli surdi obturantis aurem suam
6 Which will not hear the voice of the charmers; nor of the wizard that charmeth wisely. 6 ut non audiat vocem murmurantium nec incantatoris incantationes callidas
7 God shall break in pieces their teeth in their mouth: the Lord shall break the grinders of the lions. 7 Deus excute dentes eorum ex ore eorum molares leonum confringe Domine
8 They shall come to nothing, like water running down; he hath bent his bow till they be weakened. 8 dissolvantur quasi aquae quae defluent intendet arcum suum donec conterantur
9 Like wax that melteth they shall be taken away: fire hath fallen on them, and they shall not see the sun. 9 quasi vermis tabefactus pertranseant quasi abortivum mulieris quod non vidit solem
10 Before your thorns could know the brier; he swalloweth them up, as alive, in his wrath. 10 antequam crescant spinae vestrae in ramnum quasi viventes quasi in ira tempestas rapiet eas
11 The just shall rejoice when he shall see the revenge: he shall wash his hands in the blood of the sinner. 11 laetabitur iustus cum viderit ultionem pedes suos lavabit in sanguinem impii
12 And man shall say: If indeed there be fruit to the just: there is indeed a God that judgeth them on the earth. 12 et dicet homo vere fructus est iusto vere est Deus iudicans in terra

Chapter 58

Eripe me. A prayer to be delivered from the wicked, with confidence in God's help and protection. It agrees to Christ and his enemies the Jews.

1 Unto the end, destroy not, for David for an inscription of a title, when Saul sent and watched his house to kill him. [1 Kings 19.] 1 victori ut non disperdas David humilem et simplicem quando misit Saul et custodierunt domum ut occiderent eum
2 Deliver me from my enemies, O my God; and defend me from them that rise up against me. 2 erue me de inimicis meis Deus meus et a resistentibus mihi protege me
3 Deliver me from them that work iniquity, and save me from bloody men. 3 libera me ab operariis iniquitatis et a viris sanguinum salva me
4 For behold they have caught my soul: the mighty have rushed in upon me: 4 quia ecce insidiati sunt animae meae congregantur adversum me fortissimi
5 Neither is it my iniquity, nor my sin, O Lord: without iniquity have I run, and directed my steps. 5 absque iniquitate mea et absque peccato meo Domine non egi inique et illi currunt et praeparantur
6 Rise up thou to meet me, and behold: even thou, O Lord, the God of hosts, the God of Israel. Attend to visit all the nations: have no mercy on all them that work iniquity. 6 surge ex adverso pro me et respice et tu Domine Deus exercituum Deus Israhel evigila ut visites omnes gentes non miserearis universis qui operantur iniquitatem semper
7 They shall return at evening, and shall suffer hunger like dogs: and shall go round about the city. 7 revertantur ad vesperam et latrent ut canis et circumeant civitatem
8 Behold they shall speak with their mouth, and a sword is in their lips: for who, say they, hath heard us? 8 ecce loquuntur in ore suo gladii in labiis eorum quasi nemo audiat
9 But thou, O Lord, shalt laugh at them: thou shalt bring all the nations to nothing. 9 tu autem Domine deridebis eos subsannabis omnes gentes
10 I will keep my strength to thee: for thou art my protector: 10 fortitudinem meam ad te servabo quoniam tu Deus elevator meus
11 My God, his mercy shall prevent me. 11 Dei mei misericordia praeveniet me
12 God shall let me see over my enemies: slay them not, lest at any time my people forget. Scatter them by thy power; and bring them down, O Lord, my protector: 12 Deus ostendit mihi in insidiatoribus meis ne occidas eos ne forte obliviscantur populi mei disperge eos in fortitudine tua et destrue eos protector noster Domine
13 For the sin of their mouth, and the word of their lips: and let them be taken in their pride. And for their cursing and lying they shall be talked of, 13 in peccato oris sui in sermone labiorum suorum et capiantur in superbia sua maledictionem et mendacium narrantes
14 When they are consumed: when they are consumed by thy wrath, and they shall be no more. And they shall know that God will rule Jacob, and all the ends of the earth. 14 consume in furore consume ut non subsistant et sciant quoniam Deus dominatur Iacob in finibus terrae semper
15 They shall return at evening and shall suffer hunger like dogs: and shall go round about the city. 15 et convertantur ad vesperam et latrent ut canis et circumeant civitatem
16 They shall be scattered abroad to eat, and shall murmur if they be not filled. 16 ipsi vagabuntur ut comedant et cum saturati non fuerint murmurabunt
17 But I will sing thy strength: and will extol thy mercy in the morning. For thou art become my support, and my refuge, in the day of my trouble. 17 ego autem cantabo imperium tuum et laudabo mane misericordiam tuam quoniam factus es fortitudo mea et refugium in die tribulationis meae
18 Unto thee, O my helper, will I sing, for thou art God my defence: my God my mercy. 18 tibi cantabo quoniam Deus adiutor meus fortitudo mea Deus misericordia mea

Chapter 59

Deus, repulisti nos. After many afflictions, the church of Christ shall prevail.

1 Unto the end, for them that shall be changed, for the inscription of a title, to David himself, for doctrine, 1 victori pro liliis testimonium humilis et perfecti David ad docendum
2 When he set fire to Mesopotamia of Syria and Sobal: and Joab returned and slew of Edom, in the vale of the saltpits, twelve thousand men. 2 quando pugnavit adversum Syriam Mesopotamiae et adversum Syriam Suba et reversus est Ioab et percussit Edom in valle Salinarum duodecim milia
3 O God, thou hast cast us off, and hast destroyed us; thou hast been angry, and hast had mercy on us. 3 Deus proiecisti nos et scidisti iratus convertisti nos
4 Thou hast moved the earth, and hast troubled it: heal thou the breaches thereof, for it has been moved. 4 commovisti terram et disrupisti eam sana contritiones eius quoniam commota est
5 Thou hast shewn thy people hard things; thou hast made us drink the wine of sorrow. 5 ostendisti populo tuo duritiam potasti nos vino consopiente
6 Thou hast given a warning to them that fear thee: that they may flee from before the bow: That thy beloved may be delivered. 6 dedisti timentibus te signum ut fugerent a facie arcus semper ut liberentur amici tui
7 Save me with thy right hand, and hear me. 7 salva dextera tua et exaudi me
8 God hath spoken in his holy place: I will rejoice, and I will divide Sichem; and will mete out the vale of tabernacles. 8 Deus locutus est in sanctuario suo laetabor dividam Sicimam et vallem Soccoth dimetiar
9 Galaad is mine, and Manasses is mine: and Ephraim is the strength of my head. Juda is my king: 9 meus est Galaad et meus Manasse et Efraim fortitudo capitis mei Iudas legifer meus
10 Moab is the pot of my hope. Into Edom will I stretch out my shoe: to me the foreigners are made subject. 10 Moab olla lavacri mei super Idumeam incedam calciamento meo mihi Palestina foederata est
11 Who will bring me into the strong city? who will lead me into Edom? 11 quis deducet me ad civitatem munitam quis deducet me usque ad Idumeam
12 Wilt not thou, O God, who hast cast us off? and wilt not thou, O God, go out with our armies? 12 nonne tu Deus qui proiecisti nos et non egredieris Deus in exercitibus nostris
13 Give us help from trouble: for vain is the salvation of man. 13 da nobis auxilium in tribulatione vana est enim salus ab homine
14 Through God we shall do mightily: and he shall bring to nothing them that afflict us. 14 in Deo faciemus virtutem et ipse conculcabit tribulantes nos

Chapter 60

Exaudi, Deus. A prayer for the coming of the kingdom of Christ, which shall have no end.

1 Unto the end, in hymns, for David. 1 victori in psalmis David
2 Hear, O God, my supplication: be attentive to my prayer. 2 exaudi Deus laudationem meam intende orationi meae
3 To thee have I cried from the ends of the earth: when my heart was in anguish, thou hast exalted me on a rock. Thou hast conducted me; 3 de novissimo terrae ad te clamabo cum triste fuerit cor meum cum fortis elevabitur adversum me tu eris ductor meus
4 For thou hast been my hope; a tower of strength against the face of the enemy. 4 fuisti spes mea turris munitissima a facie inimici
5 In thy tabernacle I shall dwell for ever: I shall be protected under the covert of thy wings. 5 habitabo in tabernaculo tuo iugiter sperabo in protectione alarum tuarum semper
6 For thou, my God, hast heard my prayer: thou hast given an inheritance to them that fear thy name. 6 tu enim Deus exaudisti orationem meam dedisti hereditatem timentibus nomen tuum
7 Thou wilt add days to the days of the king: his years even to generation and generation. 7 dies super dies regis adicies annos eius donec est generatio et generatio
8 He abideth for ever in the sight of God: his mercy and truth who shall search? 8 sedebit semper ante faciem Dei misericordia et veritas servabunt eum
9 So will I sing a psalm to thy name for ever and ever: that I may pay my vows from day to day. 9 sic canam nomini tuo iugiter reddens vota mea per singulos dies

Chapter 61

Nonne Deo. The prophet encourageth himself and all others to trust in God, and serve him.

1 Unto the end, for Idithun, a psalm of David. 1 victori per Idithun canticum David
2 Shall not my soul be subject to God? for from him is my salvation. 2 attamen apud Deum silebit anima mea ex eo salus mea
3 For he is my God and my saviour: he is my protector, I shall be moved no more. 3 attamen ipse est scutum meum et salus mea fortitudo mea non commovebor amplius
4 How long do you rush in upon a man? you all kill, as if you were thrusting down a leaning wall, and a tottering fence. 4 usquequo insidiamini contra virum interficitis omnes quasi murus inclinus et maceria corruens
5 But they have thought to cast away my price; I ran in thirst: they blessed with their mouth, but cursed with their heart. 5 partem enim eius cogitaverunt expellere placuerunt sibi in mendacio ore suo singuli benedicunt et corde suo maledicunt semper
6 But be thou, O my soul, subject to God: for from him is my patience. 6 verumtamen Deo retice anima mea ab ipso enim praestolatio mea
7 For he is my God and my saviour: he is my helper, I shall not be moved. 7 ipse est fortitudo mea et salus mea susceptor meus non timebo
8 In God is my salvation and my glory: he is the God of my help, and my hope is in God. 8 in Deo salutare meum et gloria mea robur fortitudinis meae salus mea in Deo
9 Trust in him, all ye congregation of people: pour out your hearts before him. God is our helper for ever. 9 sperate in eo omni tempore populi effundite coram eo cor vestrum Deus spes nostra est semper
10 But vain are the sons of men, the sons of men are liars in the balances: that by vanity they may together deceive. 10 verumtamen vanitas filii Adam mendacium filii viri in stateris dolosis fraudulenter agunt simul
11 Trust not in iniquity, and cover not robberies: if riches abound, set not your heart upon them. 11 nolite confidere in calumnia et in rapina ne frustremini divitiae si fluxerint ne adponatis cor
12 God hath spoken once, these two things have I heard, that power belongeth to God, 12 unum locutus est Deus duo haec audivi quia imperium Dei est
13 And mercy to thee, O Lord; for thou wilt render to every man according to his works. 13 et tibi Domine misericordia quia tu reddes unicuique secundum opus suum

Chapter 62

Deus Deus meus, ad te. The prophet aspireth after God.

1 A psalm of David while he was in the desert of Edom. 1 canticum David cum esset in deserto Iuda
2 O God, my God, to thee do I watch at break of day. For thee my soul hath thirsted; for thee my flesh, O how many ways! 2 Deus fortitudo mea tu es de luce consurgam ad te sitivit te anima mea desideravit te caro mea
3 In a desert land, and where there is no way, and no water: so in the sanctuary have I come before thee, to see thy power and thy glory. 3 in terra invia et conficiente ac sine aqua sic in sancto apparui tibi ut videam fortitudinem tuam et gloriam tuam
4 For thy mercy is better than lives: thee my lips will praise. 4 melior est enim misericordia tua quam vitae labia mea laudabunt te
5 Thus will I bless thee all my life long: and in thy name I will lift up my hands. 5 sic benedicam tibi in vita mea in nomine tuo levabo manus meas
6 Let my soul be filled as with marrow and fatness: and my mouth shall praise thee with joyful lips. 6 quasi adipe et pinguidine implebitur anima mea et labiis laudantibus canet os meum
7 If I have remembered thee upon my bed, I will meditate on thee in the morning: 7 recordans tui in cubili meo per singulas vigilias meditabor tibi
8 Because thou hast been my helper. And I will rejoice under the covert of thy wings: 8 quia fuisti auxilium meum in umbra alarum tuarum laudabo
9 My soul hath stuck close to thee: thy right hand hath received me. 9 adhesit anima mea post te me suscepit dextera tua
10 But they have fought my soul in vain, they shall go into the lower parts of the earth: 10 ipsi vero interficere quaerunt animam meam ingrediantur in extrema terrae
11 They shall be delivered into the hands of the sword, they shall be the portions of foxes. 11 congregentur in manus gladii pars vulpium erunt
12 But the king shall rejoice in God, all they shall be praised that swear by him: because the mouth is stopped of them that speak wicked things. 12 rex autem laetabitur in Deo laudabitur omnis qui iurat in eo quia obstruetur os loquentium mendacium

Chapter 63

Exaudi Deus orationem. A prayer in affliction, with confidence in God that he will bring to nought the machinations of persecutors.

1 Unto the end, a psalm for David. 1 victori canticum David
2 Hear O God, my prayer, when I make supplication to thee: deliver my soul from the fear of the enemy. 2 audi Deus vocem meam loquentis a timore inimici serva vitam meam
3 Thou hast protected me from the assembly of the malignant; from the multitude of the workers of iniquity. 3 absconde me a consilio malignorum a tumultu operantium iniquitatem
4 For they have whetted their tongues like a sword; they have bent their bow a bitter thing, 4 qui exacuerunt quasi gladium linguam suam tetenderunt sagittam suam verbum amarissimum
5 To shoot in secret the undefiled. 5 ut sagittarent in absconditis simplicem
6 They will shoot at him on a sudden, and will not fear: they are resolute in wickedness. They have talked of hiding snares; they have said: Who shall see them? 6 subito sagittabunt eum et non timebunt confortaverunt sibi sermonem pessimum narraverunt ut absconderent laqueos dixerunt quis videbit nos
7 They have searched after iniquities: they have failed in their search. Man shall come to a deep heart: 7 scrutati sunt iniquitates defecerunt scrutantes scrutinio cogitationibus singulorum et corde profundo
8 And God shall be exalted. The arrows of children are their wounds: 8 sagittabit ergo eos Deus iaculo repentino inferentur plagae eorum
9 And their tongues against them are made weak. All that saw them were troubled; 9 et corruent in semet ipsos linguis suis fugient omnes qui viderint eos
10 And every man was afraid. And they declared the works of God, and understood his doings. 10 et timebunt omnes homines et adnuntiabunt opus Dei et opera eius intellegent
11 The just shall rejoice in the Lord, and shall hope in him: and all the upright in heart shall be praised. 11 laetabitur iustus in Domino et sperabit in eo et exultabunt omnes recti corde

Chapter 64

Te decet. God is to be praised in his church, to which all nations shall be called.

1 To the end, a psalm of David. The canticle of Jeremias and Ezechiel to the people of the captivity, when they began to go out. 1 victori carmen David cantici
2 A hymn, O God, becometh thee in Sion: and a vow shall be paid to thee in Jerusalem. 2 tibi silens laus Deus in Sion et tibi reddetur votum
3 O hear my prayer: all flesh shall come to thee. 3 exaudi orationem donec ad te omnis caro veniat
4 The words of the wicked have prevailed over us: and thou wilt pardon our transgressions. 4 verba iniquitatum praevaluerunt adversum me sceleribus nostris tu propitiaberis
5 Blessed is he whom thou hast chosen and taken to thee: he shall dwell in thy courts. We shall be filled with the good things of thy house; holy is thy temple, 5 beatus quem elegeris et susceperis habitabit enim in atriis tuis replebimur bonis domus tuae sanctificatione templi tui
6 Wonderful in justice. Hear us, O God our saviour, who art the hope of all the ends of the earth, and in the sea afar off. 6 terribilis in iustitia exaudi nos Deus salvator noster confidentia omnium finium terrae et maris longinqui
7 Thou who preparest the mountains by thy strength, being girded with power: 7 praeparans montes in virtute tua accinctus fortitudine
8 Who troublest the depth of the sea, the noise of its waves. The Gentiles shall be troubled, 8 conpescens sonitum maris fremitum fluctuum eius et multitudinem gentium
9 And they that dwell in the uttermost borders shall be afraid at thy signs: thou shalt make the outgoings of the morning and of the evening to be joyful. 9 et timebunt qui habitant in extremis a signis tuis egressus matutinos et vespere laudantes facies
10 Thou hast visited the earth, and hast plentifully watered it; thou hast many ways enriched it. The river of God is filled with water, thou hast prepared their food: for so is its preparation. 10 visita terram et inriga eam ubertate dita eam rivus Dei plenus aqua praeparabis frumentum eorum quia sic fundasti eam
11 Fill up plentifully the streams thereof, multiply its fruits; it shall spring up and rejoice in its showers. 11 sulcos eius inebria multiplica fruges eius pluviis inriga eam et germini eius benedic
12 Thou shalt bless the crown of the year of thy goodness: and thy fields shall be filled with plenty. 12 volvetur annus in bonitate tua et vestigia tua rorabunt pinguidine
13 The beautiful places of the wilderness shall grow fat: and the hills shall be girded about with joy, 13 pinguescent pascua deserti et exultatione colles accingentur
14 The rams of the flock are clothed, and the vales shall abound with corn: they shall shout, yea they shall sing a hymn. 14 vestientur agnis greges et valles plenae erunt frumento coaequabuntur et canent

Chapter 65

Jubilate Deo. An invitation to praise God.

1 Unto the end, a canticle of a psalm of the resurrection. Shout with joy to God, all the earth, 1 victori canticum psalmi iubilate Deo omnis terra
2 Sing ye a psalm to his name; give glory to his praise. 2 cantate gloriam nomini eius date gloriam laudi eius
3 Say unto God, How terrible are thy works, O Lord! in the multitude of thy strength thy enemies shall lie to thee. 3 dicite Deo quam terribile opus tuum in multitudine fortitudinis tuae mentientur tibi inimici tui
4 Let all the earth adore thee, and sing to thee: let it sing a psalm to thy name. 4 omnis terra adoret te et cantet tibi cantet nomini tuo semper
5 Come and see the works of God; who is terrible in his counsels over the sons of men. 5 venite et videte opera Dei terribilia consilia super filiis hominum
6 Who turneth the sea into dry land, in the river they shall pass on foot: there shall we rejoice in him. 6 convertit mare in aridam in flumine pertransibunt pede ibi laetabimur in eo
7 Who by his power ruleth for ever: his eyes behold the nations; let not them that provoke him be exalted in themselves. 7 qui dominatur in fortitudine sua saeculo oculi eius gentes aspiciunt qui increduli sunt non exaltentur in semet ipsis semper
8 O bless our God, ye Gentiles: and make the voice of his praise to be heard. 8 benedicite populi Deo nostro et auditam facite vocem laudis eius
9 Who hath set my soul to live: and hath not suffered my feet to be moved: 9 qui posuit animam nostram in vitam et non dedit in commotione pedes nostros
10 For thou, O God, hast proved us: thou hast tried us by fire, as silver is tried. 10 probasti enim nos Deus igne nos conflasti sicut conflatur argentum
11 Thou hast brought us into a net, thou hast laid afflictions on our back: 11 introduxisti nos in obsidione posuisti stridorem in dorso nostro
12 Thou hast set men over our heads. We have passed through fire and water, and thou hast brought us out into a refreshment. 12 inposuisti homines super caput nostrum transivimus per ignem et aquam et eduxisti nos in refrigerium
13 I will go into thy house with burnt offerings: I will pay thee my vows, 13 ingrediar domum tuam in holocaustis reddam tibi vota mea
14 Which my lips have uttered, And my mouth hath spoken, when I was in trouble. 14 quae promiserunt tibi labia mea et locutum est os meum cum tribularer
15 I will offer up to thee holocausts full of marrow, with burnt offerings of rams: I will offer to thee bullocks with goats. 15 holocausta medullata offeram tibi cum incensu arietum faciam boves cum hircis semper
16 Come and hear, all ye that fear God, and I will tell you what great things he hath done for my soul. 16 venite audite et narrabo omnes qui timetis Deum quanta fecerit animae meae
17 I cried to him with my mouth: and I extolled him with my tongue. 17 ipsum ore meo invocavi et exaltavi in lingua mea
18 If I have looked at iniquity in my heart, the Lord will not hear me. 18 iniquitatem si vidi in corde meo non exaudiat Dominus
19 Therefore hath God heard me, and hath attended to the voice of my supplication. 19 ideo exaudivit Deus et adtendit vocem deprecationis meae
20 Blessed be God, who hath not turned away my prayer, nor his mercy from me. 20 benedictus Deus qui non abstulit orationem meam et misericordiam suam a me

Chapter 66

Deus misereatur. A prayer for the propagation of the church.

1 Unto the end, in hymns, a psalm of a canticle for David. 1 victori in psalmis canticum carminis
2 May God have mercy on us, and bless us: may he cause the light of his countenance to shine upon us, and may he have mercy on us. 2 Deus misereatur nostri et benedicat nobis inlustret faciem suam super nos semper
3 That we may know thy way upon earth: thy salvation in all nations. 3 ut nota fiat in terra via tua in universis gentibus salus tua
4 Let people confess to thee, O God: let all people give praise to thee. 4 confiteantur tibi populi Deus confiteantur tibi populi omnes
5 Let the nations be glad and rejoice: for thou judgest the people with justice, and directest the nations upon earth. 5 laetentur et laudent gentes quoniam iudicas populos in aequitate et gentium quae in terra sunt ductor es sempiternus
6 Let the people, O God, confess to thee: let all the people give praise to thee: 6 confiteantur tibi populi Deus confiteantur tibi populi omnes
7 The earth hath yielded her fruit. May God, our God bless us, 7 terra dedit germen suum benedicat nobis Deus Deus noster
8 May God bless us: and all the ends of the earth fear him. 8 benedicat nobis Deus et timeant eum omnes fines terrae

Chapter 67

Exurgat Deus. The glorious establishment of the church of the New Testament, prefigured by the benefits bestowed on the people of Israel.

1 Unto the end, a psalm of a canticle for David himself. 1 victori David psalmus cantici
2 Let God arise, and let his enemies be scattered: and let them that hate him flee from before his face. 2 exsurgat Deus et dissipentur inimici eius et fugiant qui oderunt eum a facie eius
3 As smoke vanisheth, so let them vanish away: as wax melteth before the fire, so let the wicked perish at the presence of God. 3 sicut deficit fumus deficiant sicut tabescit cera a facie ignis pereant impii a facie Dei
4 And let the just feast, and rejoice before God: and be delighted with gladness. 4 iusti autem laetentur exultent in conspectu Dei et gaudeant in laetitia
5 Sing ye to God, sing a psalm to his name, make a way for him who ascendeth upon the west: the Lord is his name. Rejoice ye before him: but the wicked shall be troubled at his presence, 5 cantate Deo canite nomini eius praeparate viam ascendenti per deserta in Domino nomen eius et exultate coram eo
6 Who is the father of orphans, and the judge of widows. God in his holy place: 6 patri pupillorum et defensori viduarum Deus in habitaculo sancto suo
7 God who maketh men of one manner to dwell in a house: Who bringeth out them that were bound in strength; in like manner them that provoke, that dwell in sepulchres. 7 Deus habitare facit solitarios in domo educit vinctos in fortitudine increduli autem habitaverunt in siccitatibus
8 O God, when thou didst go forth in the sight of thy people, when thou didst pass through the desert: 8 Deus cum egredereris ante populum tuum et ambulares per desertum semper
9 The earth was moved, and the heavens dropped at the presence of the God of Sina, at the presence of the God of Israel. 9 terra commota est et caeli stillaverunt a facie tua Deus hoc est in Sinai a facie Dei Dei Israhel
10 Thou shalt set aside for thy inheritance a free rain, O God: and it was weakened, but thou hast made it perfect. 10 pluviam voluntariam elevasti Deus hereditatem tuam laborantem tu confortasti
11 In it shall thy animals dwell; in thy sweetness, O God, thou hast provided for the poor. 11 animalia tua habitaverunt in ea praeparasti in bonitate tua pauperi Deus
12 The Lord shall give the word to them that preach good tidings with great power. 12 Domine dabis sermonem adnuntiatricibus fortitudinis plurimae
13 The king of powers is of the beloved, of the beloved; and the beauty of the house shall divide spoils. 13 reges exercituum foederabuntur foederabuntur et pulchritudo domus dividet spolia
14 If you sleep among the midst of lots, you shall be as the wings of a dove covered with silver, and the hinder parts of her back with the paleness of gold. 14 si dormieritis inter medios terminos pinnae columbae deargentatae et posteriora eius in virore auri
15 When he that is in heaven appointeth kings over her, they shall be whited with snow in Selmon. 15 cum divideret Robustissimus reges in ea nive dealbata est in Selmon
16 The mountain of God is a fat mountain. A curdled mountain, a fat mountain. 16 mons Dei mons pinguis mons excelsus mons pinguis
17 Why suspect, ye curdled mountains? A mountain in which God is well pleased to dwell: for there the Lord shall dwell unto the end. 17 quare contenditis montes excelsi adversum montem quem dilexit Deus ut habitaret in eo siquidem Dominus habitabit semper
18 The chariot of God is attended by ten thousands; thousands of them that rejoice: the Lord is among them in Sina, in the holy place. 18 currus Dei innumerabilis milia abundantium Dominus in eis in Sina in sancto
19 Thou hast ascended on high, thou hast led captivity captive; thou hast received gifts in men. Yea for those also that do not believe, the dwelling of the Lord God. 19 ascendisti in excelsum captivam duxisti captivitatem accepisti dona in hominibus insuper et non credentes habitare Dominum Deum
20 Blessed be the Lord day by day: the God of our salvation will make our journey prosperous to us. 20 benedictus Dominus per singulos dies portabit nos Deus salutis nostrae semper
21 Our God is the God of salvation: and of the Lord, of the Lord are the issues from death. 21 Deus noster Deus salutis et Domini Dei mortis egressus
22 But God shall break the heads of his enemies: the hairy crown of them that walk on in their sins. 22 verumtamen Deus confringet capita inimicorum suorum verticem crinis ambulantis in delictis suis
23 The Lord said: I will turn them from Basan, I will turn them into the depth of the sea: 23 dixit Dominus de Basan convertam convertam de profundis maris
24 That thy foot may be dipped in the blood of thy enemies; the tongue of thy dogs be red with the same. 24 ut calcet pes tuus in sanguine lingua canum tuorum ex inimicis a temet ipso
25 They have seen thy goings, O God, the goings of my God: of my king who is in his sanctuary. 25 viderunt itinera tua Deus itinera Dei mei regis mei in sancto
26 Princes went before joined with singers, in the midst of young damsels playing on timbrels. 26 praecesserunt cantores eos qui post tergum psallebant in medio puellarum tympanistriarum
27 In the churches bless ye God the Lord, from the fountains of Israel. 27 in ecclesiis benedicite Deo Domino de fontibus Israhel
28 There is Benjamin a youth, in ecstasy of mind. The princes of Juda are their leaders: the princes of Zabulon, the princes of Nephthali. 28 ibi Beniamin parvulus continens eos principes Iuda in purpura sua principes Zabulon principes Nepthali
29 Command thy strength, O God confirm, O God, what thou hast wrought in us. 29 praecepit Deus tuus de fortitudine tua conforta Deus hoc quod operatus es nobis
30 From thy temple in Jerusalem, kings shall offer presents to thee. 30 de templo tuo quod est in Hierusalem tibi offerent reges munera
31 Rebuke the wild beasts of the reeds, the congregation of bulls with the kine of the people; who seek to exclude them who are tried with silver. Scatter thou the nations that delight in wars: 31 increpa bestiam calami congregatio fortium in vitulis populorum calcitrantium contra rotas argenteas disperge populos qui bella volunt
32 Ambassadors shall come out of Egypt: Ethiopia shall soon stretch out her hands to God. 32 offerant velociter ex Aegypto Aethiopia festinet dare manus Deo
33 Sing to God, ye kingdoms of the earth: sing ye to the Lord: Sing ye to God, 33 regna terrae cantate Deo canite Domino semper
34 Who mounteth above the heaven of heavens, to the east. Behold he will give to his voice the voice of power: 34 qui ascendit super caelum caeli a principio ecce dabit voci suae vocem fortitudinis
35 Give ye glory to God for Israel, his magnificence, and his power is in the clouds. 35 date gloriam Deo super Israhel magnificentia eius et fortitudo eius in caelis
36 God is wonderful in his saints: the God of Israel is he who will give power and strength to his people. Blessed be God. 36 terribilis Deus de sanctuario suo Deus Israhel ipse dabit fortitudinem et robur populo benedictus Deus

Chapter 68

Salvum me fac, Deus. Christ in his passion declareth the greatness of his sufferings, and the malice of his persecutors the Jews; and foretelleth their reprobation.

1 Unto the end, for them that shall be changed; for David. 1 victori pro liliis David
2 Save me, O God: for the waters are come in even unto my soul. 2 salva me Deus quoniam venerunt aquae usque ad animam
3 I stick fast in the mire of the deep and there is no sure standing. I am come into the depth of the sea, and a tempest hath overwhelmed me. 3 infixus sum in limo profundi et non possum consistere veni in profundum aquarum et flumen operuit me
4 I have laboured with crying; my jaws are become hoarse, my eyes have failed, whilst I hope in my God. 4 laboravi clamans exasperatum est guttur meum defecerunt oculi mei expectantes Deum meum
5 They are multiplied above the hairs of my head, who hate me without cause. My enemies are grown strong who have wrongfully persecuted me: then did I pay that which I took not away. 5 multiplicati sunt super capillos capitis mei qui oderunt me gratis confortati sunt qui persequebantur me inimici mei iniuste quae non rapueram tunc reddebam
6 O God, thou knowest my foolishness; and my offences are not hidden from thee: 6 Deus tu scis stultitiam meam et peccata mea a te non sunt abscondita
7 Let not them be ashamed for me, who look for thee, O Lord, the Lord of hosts. Let them not be confounded on my account, who seek thee, O God of Israel. 7 non confundantur in me qui expectant te Domine Deus exercituum non confundantur in me qui quaerunt te Deus Israhel
8 Because for thy sake I have borne reproach; shame hath covered my face. 8 quia propter te portavi obprobrium operuit confusio faciem meam
9 I am become a stranger to my brethren, and an alien to the sons of my mother. 9 alienus factus sum fratribus meis et peregrinus filiis matris meae
10 For the zeal of thy house hath eaten me up: and the reproaches of them that reproached thee are fallen upon me. 10 quia zelus domus tuae comedit me et obprobrium exprobrantium tibi cecidit super me
11 And I covered my soul in fasting: and it was made a reproach to me. 11 et flevi in ieiunio animam meam et factum est in obprobria mihi
12 And I made haircloth my garment: and I became a byword to them. 12 et posui vestimentum meum saccum et factus sum eis in parabulam
13 They that sat in the gate spoke against me: and they that drank wine made me their song. 13 contra me loquebantur qui sedebant in porta et cantabant bibentes vinum
14 But as for me, my prayer is to thee, O Lord; for the time of thy good pleasure, O God. In the multitude of thy mercy hear me, in the truth of thy salvation. 14 mea autem oratio ad te Domine tempus reconciliationis est Deus in multitudine misericordiae tuae exaudi me in veritate salutaris tui
15 Draw me out of the mire, that I may not stick fast: deliver me from them that hate me, and out of the deep waters. 15 erue me de luto ut non infigar libera me ab his qui oderunt me et de profundis aquis
16 Let not the tempest of water drown me, nor the deep water swallow me up: and let not the pit shut her mouth upon me. 16 ne operiat me fluvius aquae et ne absorbeat me profundum et non coronet super me puteus os suum
17 Hear me, O Lord, for thy mercy is kind; look upon me according to the multitude of thy tender mercies. 17 exaudi me Domine quoniam bona est misericordia tua secundum multitudinem miserationum tuarum respice ad me
18 And turn not away thy face from thy servant: for I am in trouble, hear me speedily. 18 et ne abscondas faciem tuam a servo tuo quoniam tribulor cito exaudi me
19 Attend to my soul, and deliver it: save me because of my enemies. 19 accede ad animam meam redime eam propter inimicos meos libera me
20 Thou knowest my reproach, and my confusion, and my shame. 20 tu scis obprobrium meum et confusionem meam et ignominiam meam
21 In thy sight are all they that afflict me; my heart hath expected reproach and misery. And I looked for one that would grieve together with me, but there was none: and for one that would comfort me, and I found none. 21 coram te sunt omnes hostes mei obprobrio contritum est cor meum et desperatus sum et expectavi qui contristaretur et non fuit et qui consolaretur et non inveni
22 And they gave me gall for my food, and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink. 22 et dederunt in esca mea fel et in siti mea potaverunt me aceto
23 Let their table become as a snare before them, and a recompense, and a stumblingblock. 23 sit mensa eorum coram eis in laqueum et in retributiones ad corruendum
24 Let their eyes be darkened that they see not; and their back bend thou down always. 24 contenebrentur oculi eorum ne videant et dorsum eorum semper incurva
25 Pour out thy indignation upon them: and let thy wrathful anger take hold of them. 25 effunde super eos indignationem tuam et ira furoris tui conprehendat eos
26 Let their habitation be made desolate: and let there be none to dwell in their tabernacles. 26 fiat commoratio eorum deserta in tabernaculis eorum non sit qui habitet
27 Because they have persecuted him whom thou hast smitten; and they have added to the grief of my wounds. 27 quoniam quem tu percussisti persecuti sunt et ut adfligerent vulneratos tuos narrabant
28 Add thou iniquity upon their iniquity: and let them not come into thy justice. 28 da iniquitatem super iniquitatem eorum et non veniant in iustitia tua
29 Let them be blotted out of the book of the living; and with the just let them not be written. 29 deleantur de libro viventium et cum iustis non scribantur
30 But I am poor and sorrowful: thy salvation, O God, hath set me up. 30 ego autem pauper et dolens salus tua Deus suscipiet me
31 I will praise the name of God with a canticle: and I will magnify him with praise. 31 laudabo nomen Dei in cantico et magnificabo eum in confessione
32 And it shall please God better than a young calf, that bringeth forth horns and hoofs. 32 et placebit Domino super vitulum novellum cornua efferentem et ungulas
33 Let the poor see and rejoice: seek ye God, and your soul shall live. 33 videntes mansueti laetabuntur qui quaeritis Deum vivet anima vestra
34 For the Lord hath heard the poor: and hath not despised his prisoners. 34 quoniam exaudivit pauperes Dominus et vinctos suos non dispexit
35 Let the heavens and the earth praise him; the sea, and every thing that creepeth therein. 35 laudent eum caeli et terra maria et omne quod movetur in eis
36 For God will save Sion, and the cities of Juda shall be built up. And they shall dwell there, and acquire it by inheritance. 36 quia Deus salvabit Sion et aedificabit civitates Iuda et habitabunt ibi et possidebunt eam
37 And the seed of his servants shall possess it; and they that love his name shall dwell therein. 37 et semen servorum eius possidebit eam et qui diligunt nomen eius habitabunt in ea

Chapter 69

Deus in adjutorium. A prayer in persecution.

1 Unto the end, a psalm for David, to bring to remembrance that the Lord saved him. 1 victori David ad recordandum
2 O God, come to my assistance; O Lord, make haste to help me. 2 Deus ut liberes me Domine ut auxilieris mihi festina
3 Let them be confounded and ashamed that seek my soul: 3 confundantur et erubescant qui quaerunt animam meam
4 Let them be turned backward, and blush for shame that desire evils to me: Let them be presently turned away blushing for shame that say to me: 'Tis well, 'tis well. 4 convertantur retrorsum et erubescant qui volunt malum mihi revertantur ad vestigium confusionis suae qui dicunt va va
5 Let all that seek thee rejoice and be glad in thee; and let such as love thy salvation say always: The Lord be magnified. 5 gaudeant et laetentur in te omnes qui quaerunt te et dicant semper magnificetur Deus qui diligunt salutare tuum
6 But I am needy and poor; O God, help me. Thou art my helper and my deliverer: O lord, make no delay. 6 ego autem egenus et pauper Deus festina pro me auxilium meum et salvator meus tu Domine ne moreris

Chapter 70

In te, Domine. A prayer for perseverance.

1 A psalm for David. Of the sons of Jonadab, and the former captives. In thee, O Lord, I have hoped, let me never be put to confusion: 1 in te Domine speravi ne confundar in aeternum
2 Deliver me in thy justice, and rescue me. Incline thy ear unto me, and save me. 2 iustitia tua erue me et libera inclina ad me aurem tuam et salva me
3 Be thou unto me a God, a protector, and a place of strength: that thou mayst make me safe. For thou art my firmament and my refuge. 3 esto mihi robustum habitaculum ut ingrediar iugiter praecepisti ut salvares me quia petra mea et fortitudo mea es tu
4 Deliver me, O my God, out of the hand of the sinner, and out of the hand of the transgressor of the law and of the unjust. 4 Deus meus salva me de manu impii de manu iniqui et nocentis
5 For thou art my patience, O Lord: my hope, O Lord, from my youth. 5 quia tu es expectatio mea Deus Domine fiducia mea ab adulescentia mea
6 By thee have I been confirmed from the womb: from my mother's womb thou art my protector. Of thee I shall continually sing: 6 a te sustentatus sum ex utero de ventre matris meae tu es protector meus in te laus mea semper
7 I am become unto many as a wonder, but thou art a strong helper. 7 quasi portentum factus sum multis et tu spes mea fortissima
8 Let my mouth be filled with praise, that I may sing thy glory; thy greatness all the day long. 8 impleatur os meum laude tua tota die magnitudine tua
9 Cast me not off in the time of old age: when my strength shall fail, do not thou forsake me. 9 ne proicias me in tempore senectutis cum defecerit fortitudo mea ne derelinquas me
10 For my enemies have spoken against me; and they that watched my soul have consulted together, 10 quia dixerunt inimici mei mihi et qui observabant animam meam inierunt consilium pariter
11 Saying: God hath forsaken him: pursue and take him, for there is none to deliver him. 11 dicentes Deus dereliquit eum persequimini et conprehendite eum quia non est qui eruat
12 O God, be not thou far from me: O my God, make haste to my help. 12 Deus ne elongeris a me Deus meus ad auxiliandum mihi festina
13 Let them be confounded and come to nothing that detract my soul; let them be covered with confusion and blame that seek my hurt. 13 confundantur et consumantur adversarii animae meae operiantur obprobrio et confusione qui quaerunt malum mihi
14 But I will always hope; and will add to all thy praise. 14 ego autem iugiter expectabo et adiciam super omnes laudationes tuas
15 My mouth shall shew forth thy justice; thy salvation all the day long. Because I have not known learning, 15 os meum narrabit iustitiam tuam tota die salutare tuum quia non cognovi litteraturas
16 I will enter into the powers of the Lord: O Lord, I will be mindful of thy justice alone. 16 ingrediar in fortitudine Domini Dei recordabor iustitiae tuae solius
17 Thou hast taught me, O God, from my youth: and till now I will declare thy wonderful works. 17 Deus docuisti me ab adulescentia mea et usque nunc adnuntiabo mirabilia tua
18 And unto old age and grey hairs: O God, forsake me not, Until I shew forth thy arm to all the generation that is to come: Thy power, 18 insuper et usque ad senectutem et canos Deus ne derelinquas me donec adnuntiem brachium tuum generationi cunctisque qui venturi sunt fortitudines tuas
19 And thy justice, O God, even to the highest great things thou hast done: O God, who is like to thee? 19 et iustitiam tuam Deus usque in excelsum quanta fecisti magnalia Deus quis similis tibi
20 How great troubles hast thou shewn me, many and grievous: and turning thou hast brought me to life, and hast brought me back again from the depths of the earth: 20 qui ostendisti mihi tribulationes plurimas et adflictiones conversus vivificabis nos et de abyssis terrae rursum educes nos
21 Thou hast multiplied thy magnificence; and turning to me thou hast comforted me. 21 multiplicabis magnitudinem meam et conversus consolaberis me
22 For I will also confess to thee thy truth with the instruments of psaltery: O God, I will sing to thee with the harp, thou holy one of Israel. 22 ego autem confitebor tibi in vasis psalterii veritatem tuam Deus meus cantabo tibi in cithara Sancte Israhel
23 My lips shall greatly rejoice, when I shall sing to thee; and my soul which thou hast redeemed. 23 laudabunt labia mea cum cantavero tibi et anima mea quam redemisti
24 Yea and my tongue shall meditate on thy justice all the day; when they shall be confounded and put to shame that seek evils to me. 24 insuper et lingua mea tota die meditabitur iustitiam tuam quia confusi sunt et dehonestati quaerentes malum mihi

Chapter 71

Deus, judicium tuum. A prophecy of the coming of Christ, and of his kingdom: prefigured by Solomon and his happy reign.

1 A psalm on Solomon. 1 Salomonis
2 Give to the king thy judgment, O God, and to the king's son thy justice: To judge thy people with justice, and thy poor with judgment. 2 Deus iudicium regi da et iustitiam tuam filio regis iudicabit populum tuum in iustitia et pauperes tuos in iudicio
3 Let the mountains receive peace for the people: and the hills justice. 3 adsument montes pacem populo et colles iustitiam
4 He shall judge the poor of the people, and he shall save the children of the poor: and he shall humble the oppressor. 4 iudicabit pauperes populi salvabit filios pauperis et confringet calumniatorem
5 And he shall continue with the sun and before the moon, throughout all generations. 5 et timebunt te quamdiu erit sol et ultra lunam in generatione generationum
6 He shall come down like rain upon the fleece; and as showers falling gently upon the earth. 6 descendet ut pluvia super vellus ut stillae inrorantes terram
7 In his days shall justice spring up, and abundance of peace, till the moon be taken away. 7 germinabit in diebus eius iustitia et multitudo pacis donec non sit luna
8 And he shall rule from sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth. 8 et dominabitur a mari usque ad mare et a flumine usque ad terminos terrae
9 Before him the Ethiopians shall fall down: and his enemies shall lick the ground. 9 ante eum procident Aethiopes et inimici eius pulverem lingent
10 The kings of Tharsis and the islands shall offer presents: the kings of the Arabians and of Saba shall bring gifts: 10 reges Tharsis et insulae munera offerent reges Arabiae et Saba tributum conferent
11 And all kings of the earth shall adore him: all nations shall serve him. 11 et adorabunt eum omnes reges universae nationes servient ei
12 For he shall deliver the poor from the mighty: and the needy that had no helper. 12 quia eruet pauperem a potente et inopem cui non est adiutor
13 He shall spare the poor and needy: and he shall save the souls of the poor. 13 parcet inopi et pauperi et animas pauperum salvabit
14 He shall redeem their souls from usuries and iniquity: and their names shall be honourable in his sight. 14 ab usura et iniquitate redimet animam eorum et pretiosus erit sanguis eorum coram oculis eius
15 And he shall live, and to him shall be given of the gold of Arabia, for him they shall always adore: they shall bless him all the day. 15 et vivet et dabitur ei de auro Saba et orabunt de eo iugiter tota die benedicent ei
16 And there shall be a firmament on the earth on the tops of mountains, above Libanus shall the fruit thereof be exalted: and they of the city shall flourish like the grass of the earth. 16 erit memorabile triticum in terra in capite montium elevabitur sicut Libani fructus eius et florebunt de civitate sicut faenum terrae
17 Let his name be blessed for evermore: his name continueth before the sun. And in him shall all the tribes of the earth be blessed: all nations shall magnify him. 17 erit nomen eius in aeternum ultra solem perseverabit nomen eius et benedicentur in eo omnes gentes et beatificabunt eum
18 Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who alone doth wonderful things. 18 benedictus Dominus Deus Deus Israhel qui facit mirabilia solus
19 And blessed be the name of his majesty for ever: and the whole earth shall be filled with his majesty. So be it. So be it. 19 et benedictum nomen gloriae eius in sempiternum et implebitur gloria eius universa terra amen amen
20 The praises of David, the son of Jesse, are ended. 20 conpletae sunt orationes David filii Iesse

Chapter 72

Quam bonus Israel Deus. The temptation of the weak, upon seeing the prosperity of the wicked, is overcome by the consideration of the justice of God, who will quickly render to every one according to his works.

1 A psalm for Asaph. How good is God to Israel, to them that are of a right heart! 1 canticum Asaph attamen bonus est Israhel Deus his qui mundo sunt corde
2 But my feet were almost moved; my steps had well nigh slipped. 2 mei autem paene vacillaverunt pedes paene effusi sunt gressus mei
3 Because I had a zeal on occasion of the wicked, seeing the prosperity of sinners. 3 quia aemulatus sum contra iniquos pacem impiorum videns
4 For there is no regard to their death, nor is there strength in their stripes. 4 quod non recogitaverint de morte sua et firma sint vestibula eorum
5 They are not in the labour of men: neither shall they be scourged like other men. 5 in labore hominum non sunt et cum hominibus non flagellabuntur
6 Therefore pride hath held them fast: they are covered with their iniquity and their wickedness. 6 ideo nutriti sunt ad superbiam circumdederunt iniquitatem sibi
7 Their iniquity hath come forth, as it were from fatness: they have passed into the affection of the heart. 7 processerunt a pinguidine oculi eorum transierunt cogitationes cordis
8 They have thought and spoken wickedness: they have spoken iniquity on high. 8 inriserunt et locuti sunt in malitia calumniam de excelso loquentes
9 They have set their mouth against heaven: and their tongue hath passed through the earth. 9 posuerunt in caelo os suum et lingua eorum deambulavit in terra
10 Therefore will my people return here and full days shall be found in them. 10 propterea convertetur populus eius hic et quis plenus invenietur in eis
11 And they said: How doth God know? and is there knowledge in the most High? 11 et dixerunt quomodo novit Deus et si est scientia in Excelso
12 Behold these are sinners; and yet, abounding in the world they have obtained riches. 12 ecce isti impii et abundantes in saeculo multiplicaverunt divitias
13 And I said: Then have I in vain justified my heart, and washed my hands among the innocent. 13 ergone frustra mundavi cor meum et lavi in innocentia manus meas
14 And I have been scourged all the day; and my chastisement hath been in the mornings. 14 et fui flagellatus tota die et increpatio mea in matutinis
15 If I said: I will speak thus; behold I should condemn the generation of thy children. 15 dixi si narravero sic ecce generationem filiorum tuorum reliqui
16 I studied that I might know this thing, it is a labour in my sight: 16 et cogitavi ut intellegerem istud labor est in oculis meis
17 Until I go into the sanctuary of God, and understand concerning their last ends. 17 donec veniam ad sanctuaria Dei intellegam in novissimo eorum
18 But indeed for deceits thou hast put it to them: when they were lifted up thou hast cast them down. 18 verumtamen in lubrico posuisti eos deiecisti eos ad interitum
19 How are they brought to desolation? they have suddenly ceased to be: they have perished by reason of their iniquity. 19 quomodo vastati sunt subito defecerunt consumpti sunt quasi non sint
20 As the dream of them that awake, O Lord; so in thy city thou shalt bring their image to nothing. 20 quasi somnium evigilantis Domine in civitate tua imaginem eorum ad nihilum rediges
21 For my heart hath been inflamed, and my reins have been changed: 21 quia contractum est cor meum et lumbi mei velut ignis fumigans
22 And I am brought to nothing, and I knew not. 22 et ego insipiens et nescius
23 I am become as a beast before thee: and I am always with thee. 23 quasi iumentum factus sum apud te et eram semper tecum
24 Thou hast held me by my right hand; and by thy will thou hast conducted me, and with thy glory thou hast received me. 24 et tenebas manum dexteram meam in consilium tuum deduces me et postea in gloria suscipies me
25 For what have I in heaven? and besides thee what do I desire upon earth? 25 quid mihi est in caelo et tecum nolui in terra
26 For thee my flesh and my heart hath fainted away: thou art the God of my heart, and the God that is my portion for ever. 26 consumpta est caro mea et cor meum robur cordis mei et pars mea Deus in aeternum
27 For behold they that go far from thee shall perish: thou hast destroyed all them that are disloyal to thee. 27 quia ecce qui elongant se a te peribunt perdidisti omnem fornicantem a te
28 But it is good for me to adhere to my God, to put my hope in the Lord God: That I may declare all thy praises, in the gates of the daughter of Sion. 28 mihi autem adpropinquare Deo bonum est posui in Domino Deo spem meam ut narrem omnes adnuntiationes tuas

Chapter 73

Ut quid, Deus. A prayer of the church under grievous persecutions.

1 Understanding for Asaph. O God, why hast thou cast us off unto the end: why is thy wrath enkindled against the sheep of thy pasture? 1 eruditionis Asaph ut quid Deus reppulisti in finem fumavit furor tuus in gregem pascuae tuae
2 Remember thy congregation, which thou hast possessed from the beginning. The sceptre of thy inheritance which thou hast redeemed: mount Sion in which thou hast dwelt. 2 recordare congregationis tuae quam possedisti ab initio et redemisti virgam hereditatis tuae montis Sion in quo habitasti
3 Lift up thy hands against their pride unto the end; see what things the enemy hath done wickedly in the sanctuary. 3 sublimitas pedum tuorum dissipata est usque ad finem omnia mala egit inimicus in sanctuario
4 And they that hate thee have made their boasts, in the midst of thy solemnity. They have set up their ensigns for signs, 4 fremuerunt hostes tui in medio pacti tui posuerunt signa sua in tropeum
5 And they knew not both in the going out and on the highest top. As with axes in a wood of trees, 5 manifesta in introitu desuper in saltu lignorum secures
6 They have cut down at once the gates thereof, with axe and hatchet they have brought it down. 6 et nunc scalpturas eius pariter bipinne et dolatoriis deraserunt
7 They have set fire to thy sanctuary: they have defiled the dwelling place of thy name on the earth. 7 miserunt ignem in sanctuarium tuum in terram contaminaverunt habitaculum nominis tui
8 They said in their heart, the whole kindred of them together: Let us abolish all the festival days of God from the land. 8 dixerunt in cordibus suis posteri eorum simul incenderunt omnes sollemnitates Dei in terra
9 Our signs we have not seen, there is now no prophet: and he will know us no more. 9 signa nostra non vidimus non est ultra propheta et non est nobiscum qui sciat usquequo
10 How long, O God, shall the enemy reproach: is the adversary to provoke thy name for ever? 10 usquequo Deus exprobrabit adversarius blasphemabit inimicus nomen tuum in finem
11 Why dost thou turn away thy hand: and thy right hand out of the midst of thy bosom for ever? 11 quare convertis manum tuam et dexteram tuam ad medium sinum tuum consume
12 But God is our king before ages: he hath wrought salvation in the midst of the earth. 12 Deus autem rex meus ab initio operatur salutes in medio terrae
13 Thou by thy strength didst make the sea firm: thou didst crush the heads of the dragons in the waters. 13 tu dissipasti in fortitudine tua mare contrivisti capita draconum in aquis
14 Thou hast broken the heads of the dragon: thou hast given him to be meat for the people of the Ethiopians. 14 tu confregisti capita Leviathan dedisti eum in escam populo Aethiopum
15 Thou hast broken up the fountains and the torrents: thou hast dried up the Ethan rivers. 15 tu disrupisti fontem et torrentem tu exsiccasti flumina fortia
16 Thine is the day, and thine is the night: thou hast made the morning light and the sun. 16 tua est dies et tua est nox tu ordinasti luminaria et solem
17 Thou hast made all the borders of the earth: the summer and the spring were formed by thee. 17 tu statuisti omnes terminos terrae aestatem et hiemem tu plasmasti
18 Remember this, the enemy hath reproached the Lord: and a foolish people hath provoked thy name. 18 memento huius inimicus exprobravit Domino et populus insipiens blasphemavit nomen tuum
19 Deliver not up to beasts the souls that confess to thee: and forget not to the end the souls of thy poor. 19 ne tradas bestiis animam eruditam lege tua vitae pauperum tuorum ne obliviscaris in perpetuum
20 Have regard to thy covenant: for they that are the obscure of the earth have been filled with dwellings of iniquity. 20 respice ad pactum quia repletae sunt tenebris terrae habitationes iniquae subrutae
21 Let not the humble be turned away with confusion: the poor and needy shall praise thy name. 21 ne revertatur confractus et confusus egenus et pauper laudabunt nomen tuum
22 Arise, O God, judge thy own cause: remember thy reproaches with which the foolish man hath reproached thee all the day. 22 surge Deus iudica causam tuam memento obprobrii tui ab insipiente tota die
23 Forget not the voices of thy enemies: the pride of them that hate thee ascendeth continually. 23 ne obliviscaris vocis hostium tuorum sonitus adversariorum tuorum ascendit iugiter

Chapter 74

Confitebimur tibi. There is a just judgment to come: therefore let the wicked take care.

1 Unto the end, corrupt not, a psalm of a canticle for Asaph. 1 victori ut non disperdas psalmus Asaph cantici
2 We will praise thee, O God: we will praise, and we will call upon thy name. We will relate thy wondrous works: 2 confitebimur tibi Deus confitebimur et iuxta nomen tuum narrabunt mirabilia tua
3 When I shall take a time, I will judge justices. 3 cum accepero tempus ego iustitias iudicabo
4 The earth is melted, and all that dwell therein: I have established the pillars thereof. 4 dissolvetur terra cum omnibus habitatoribus suis ego adpendi columnas eius semper
5 I said to the wicked: Do not act wickedly: and to the sinners: Lift not up the horn. 5 dixi inique agentibus nolite inique agere et impiis nolite exaltare cornu
6 Lift not up your horn on high: speak not iniquity against God. 6 nolite exaltare in excelsum cornu vestrum loquentes in cervice veteri
7 For neither from the east, nor from the west, nor from the desert hills: 7 quia nec ab oriente neque ab occidente neque a solitudine montium
8 For God is the judge. One he putteth down, and another he lifteth up: 8 sed Deus iudex hunc humiliabit et hunc exaltabit
9 For in the hand of the Lord there is a cup of strong wine full of mixture. And he hath poured it out from this to that: but the dregs thereof are not emptied: all the sinners of the earth shall drink. 9 quia calix in manu Domini est et vino meraco usque ad plenum mixtus et propinabit ex eo verumtamen feces eius epotabunt bibentes omnes impii terrae
10 But I will declare for ever: I will sing to the God of Jacob. 10 ego autem adnuntiabo in sempiternum cantabo Deo Iacob
11 And I will break all the horns of sinners: but the horns of the just shall be exalted. 11 et omnia cornua impiorum confringam exaltabuntur cornua iusti

Chapter 75

Notus in Judaea. God is known in his church: and exerts his power in protecting it. It alludes to the slaughter of the Assyrians, in the days of king Ezechias.

1 Unto the end, in praises, a psalm for Asaph: a canticle to the Assyrians. 1 victori in psalmis canticum Asaph carminis
2 In Judea God is known: his name is great in Israel. 2 cognoscetur in Iudaea Deus in Israhel magnum nomen eius
3 And his place is in peace: and his abode in Sion: 3 et erit in Salem tabernaculum eius et habitatio eius in Sion
4 There hath he broken the powers of bows, the shield, the sword, and the battle. 4 ibi confringet volatilia arcus scutum et gladium et bellum semper
5 Thou enlightenest wonderfully from the everlasting hills. 5 lumen tu es Magnifice a montibus captivitatis
6 All the foolish of heart were troubled. They have slept their sleep; and all the men of riches have found nothing in their hands. 6 spoliati sunt superbi corde dormitaverunt somnum suum et non invenerunt omnes viri exercitus manus suas
7 At thy rebuke, O God of Jacob, they have all slumbered that mounted on horseback. 7 ab increpatione tua Deus Iacob consopitus est et currus et equus
8 Thou art terrible, and who shall resist thee? from that time thy wrath. 8 tu terribilis es et quis stabit adversum te ex tunc ira tua
9 Thou hast caused judgment to be heard from heaven: the earth trembled and was still, 9 de caelo adnuntiabis iudicium terra timens tacebit
10 When God arose in judgment, to save all the meek of the earth. 10 cum surrexerit ad iudicandum Deus ut salvos faciat omnes mites terrae semper
11 For the thought of man shall give praise to thee: and the remainders of the thought shall keep holiday to thee. 11 quia ira hominis confitebitur tibi reliquiis irae accingeris
12 Vow ye, and pay to the Lord your God: all you that are round about him bring presents. To him that is terrible, 12 vovete et reddite Domino Deo vestro omnes qui in circuitu eius sunt offerent dona terribili
13 Even to him who taketh away the spirit of princes: to the terrible with the kings of the earth. 13 auferenti spiritum ducum terribili regibus terrae

Chapter 76

Voce mea. The faithful have recourse to God in trouble of mind, with confidence in his mercy and power.

1 Unto the end, for Idithun, a psalm of Asaph. 1 victori per Idithun psalmus Asaph
2 I cried to the Lord with my voice; to God with my voice, and he gave ear to me. 2 voce mea ad Dominum clamavi voce mea ad Dominum et exaudivit me
3 In the days of my trouble I sought God, with my hands lifted up to him in the night, and I was not deceived. My soul refused to be comforted: 3 in die tribulationis meae Dominum requisivi manus mea nocte extenditur et non quiescit noluit consolari anima mea
4 I remembered God, and was delighted, and was exercised, and my spirit swooned away. 4 recordans Dei conturbabar loquebar in memet ipso et deficiebat spiritus meus semper
5 My eyes prevented the watches: I was troubled, and I spoke not. 5 prohibebam suspectum oculorum meorum stupebam et non loquebar
6 I thought upon the days of old: and I had in my mind the eternal years. 6 recogitabam dies antiquos annos pristinos
7 And I meditated in the night with my own heart: and I was exercised and I swept my spirit. 7 recordabar psalmorum meorum in nocte cum corde meo loquebar et scobebam spiritum meum
8 Will God then cast off for ever? or will he never be more favourable again? 8 ergone in aeternum proiciet Dominus et non repropitiabitur ultra
9 Or will he cut off his mercy for ever, from generation to generation? 9 ergone conplebit usque in finem misericordiam suam consummabit verbum de generatione et generatione
10 Or will God forget to shew mercy? or will he in his anger shut up his mercies? 10 numquid oblitus est misereri Deus aut conplebit in furore misericordias suas semper
11 And I said, Now have I begun: this is the change of the right hand of the most High. 11 et dixi inbecillitas mea est haec commutatio dexterae Excelsi
12 I remembered the works of the Lord: for I will be mindful of thy wonders from the beginning. 12 recordabor cogitationum Domini reminiscens antiqua mirabilia tua
13 And I will meditate on all thy works: and will be employed in thy inventions. 13 et meditabor in omni opere tuo et adinventiones tuas loquar
14 Thy way, O God, is in the holy place: who is the great God like our God? 14 Deus in sanctuario via tua quis deus magnus ut Deus
15 Thou art the God that dost wonders. Thou hast made thy power known among the nations: 15 tu es Deus faciens mirabilia ostendens in populis potentiam tuam
16 With thy arm thou hast redeemed thy people the children of Jacob and of Joseph. 16 redemisti in brachio populum tuum filios Iacob et Ioseph semper
17 The waters saw thee, O God, the waters saw thee: and they were afraid, and the depths were troubled. 17 videntes te aquae Deus videntes te aquae parturierunt et commotae sunt abyssi
18 Great was the noise of the waters: the clouds sent out a sound. For thy arrows pass: 18 excusserunt aquas nubila vocem dederunt nubes et sagittae tuae discurrebant
19 The voice of thy thunder in a wheel. Thy lightnings enlightened the world: the earth shook and trembled. 19 vox tonitrui tui in rota apparuerunt fulgora tua orbi concussa est et commota est terra
20 Thy way is in the sea, and thy paths in many waters: and thy footsteps shall not be known. 20 in mari via tua et semitae tuae in aquis multis et vestigia tua non sunt agnita
21 Thou hast conducted thy people like sheep, by the hand of Moses and Aaron. 21 deduxisti quasi gregem populum tuum in manu Mosi et Aaron

Chapter 77

Attendite. God's great benefits to the people of Israel, notwithstanding their ingratitude.

1 Understanding for Asaph. Attend, O my people, to my law: incline your ears to the words of my mouth. 1 eruditionis Asaph ausculta populus meus legem meam inclinate aurem vestram ad verba oris mei
2 I will open my mouth in parables: I will utter propositions from the beginning. 2 aperiam in parabula os meum loquar enigmata antiqua
3 How great things have we heard and known, and our fathers have told us. 3 quae audivimus et cognovimus et patres nostri narraverunt nobis
4 They have not been hidden from their children, in another generation. Declaring the praises of the Lord, and his powers, and his wonders which he hath done. 4 non sunt abscondita a filiis eorum a generatione sequenti narrante laudes Domini et potentiam eius et mirabilia eius quae fecit
5 And he set up a testimony in Jacob: and made a law in Israel. How great things he commanded our fathers, that they should make the same known to their children: 5 statuit contestationem Iacob et legem posuit in Israhel quae mandavit patribus nostris ut docerent filios suos
6 That another generation might know them. The children that should be born and should rise up, and declare them to their children. 6 ut cognosceret generatio subsequens filii nascituri surgent et narrabunt filiis suis
7 That they may put their hope in God and may not forget the works of God: and may seek his commandments. 7 ut ponant in Deo spem suam et non obliviscantur cogitationum eius et mandata eius custodiant
8 That they may not become like their fathers, a perverse and exasperating generation. A generation that set not their heart aright: and whose spirit was not faithful to God. 8 ut non sint sicut patres eorum generatio declinans et provocans generatio quae non praeparavit cor suum et non credidit Deo spiritus eius
9 The sons of Ephraim who bend and shoot with the bow: they have turned back in the day of battle. 9 filii Efraim intendentes et mittentes arcum terga verterunt in die belli
10 They kept not the covenant of God: and in his law they would not walk. 10 non custodierunt pactum Dei sui et in lege eius noluerunt ingredi
11 And they forgot his benefits, and his wonders that he had shewn them. 11 et obliti sunt commutationum eius et mirabilium eius quae ostendit eis
12 Wonderful things did he do in the sight of their fathers, in the land of Egypt, in the field of Tanis. 12 coram patribus eorum fecit mirabilia in terra Aegypto in regione Taneos
13 He divided the sea and brought them through: and he made the waters to stand as in a vessel. 13 divisit mare et transduxit eos et stare fecit aquas quasi acervum
14 And he conducted them with a cloud by day: and all the night with a light of fire. 14 et duxit eos in nube per diem et tota nocte in lumine ignis
15 He struck the rock in the wilderness: and gave them to drink, as out of the great deep. 15 scidit petram in deserto et potum dedit quasi de abyssis magnis
16 He brought forth water out of the rock: and made streams run down as rivers. 16 et eduxit rivos de petra et elicuit quasi flumina aquas
17 And they added yet more sin against him: they provoked the most High to wrath in the place without water. 17 et addiderunt ultra peccare ei ut provocarent Excelsum in invio
18 And they tempted God in their hearts, by asking meat for their desires. 18 et temptaverunt Deum in cordibus suis petentes cibum animae suae
19 And they spoke ill of God: they said: Can God furnish a table in the wilderness? 19 et loquentes contra Deum dicebant numquid poterit Deus ponere mensam in solitudine
20 Because he struck the rock, and the waters gushed out, and the streams overflowed. Can he also give bread, or provide a table for his people? 20 ecce percussit petram et fluxerunt aquae et torrentes inundaverunt numquid et panem poterit dare aut praeparare carnem populo suo
21 Therefore the Lord heard, and was angry: and a fire was kindled against Jacob, and wrath came up against Israel. 21 ideo audivit Dominus et non distulit et ignis accensus est in Iacob et furor ascendit in Israhel
22 Because they believed not in God: and trusted not in his salvation. 22 quia non crediderunt Deo nec habuerunt fiduciam in salutari eius
23 And he had commanded the clouds from above, and had opened the doors of heaven. 23 et praecepit nubibus desuper et portas caeli aperuit
24 And had rained down manna upon them to eat, and had given them the bread of heaven. 24 et pluit super eos man ut comederent et triticum caeli dedit eis
25 Man ate the bread of angels: he sent them provisions in abundance. 25 panem fortium comedit vir cibaria misit eis in saturitatem
26 He removed the south wind from heaven: and by his power brought in the southwest wind. 26 abstulit eurum de caelo et induxit in fortitudine sua africum
27 And he rained upon them flesh as dust: and feathered fowls like as the sand of the sea. 27 et pluit super eos quasi pulverem carnes et quasi harenam maris volatilia pinnata
28 And they fell in the midst of their camp, round about their pavilions. 28 et ceciderunt in medio castrorum eius in circuitu tabernaculorum eius
29 So they did eat, and were filled exceedingly, and he gave them their desire: 29 et comederunt et saturati sunt nimis et desiderium eorum adtulit eis
30 they were not defrauded of that which they craved. As yet their meat was in their mouth: 30 non indiguerunt de cupiditate sua cum adhuc cibus esset in ore eorum
31 And the wrath of God came upon them. And he slew the fat ones amongst them, and brought down the chosen men of Israel. 31 furor ergo Dei ascendit super eos et occidit pingues eorum et electos Israhel incurvavit
32 In all these things they sinned still: and they behaved not for his wondrous works. 32 in omnibus his peccaverunt ultra et non crediderunt mirabilibus eius
33 And their days were consumed in vanity, and their years in haste. 33 et consumpsit in vanitate dies eorum et annos eorum velociter
34 When he slew them, then they sought him: and they returned, and came to him early in the morning. 34 si occidebat eos tunc requirebant eum et convertebantur et diluculo consurgebant ad Deum
35 And they remembered that God was their helper: and the most high God their redeemer. 35 et recordabantur quia Deus fortitudo eorum et Deus excelsus redemptor eorum
36 And they loved him with their mouth: and with their tongue they lied unto him: 36 et lactaverunt eum in ore suo et lingua sua mentiti sunt ei
37 But their heart was not right with him: nor were they counted faithful in his covenant. 37 cor autem eorum non erat firmum cum eo nec permanserunt in pacto eius
38 But he is merciful, and will forgive their sins: and will not destroy them. And many a time did he turn away his anger: and did not kindle all his wrath. 38 ipse vero misericors propitiabitur iniquitati et non disperdet multumque avertit iram suam et non suscitavit totum furorem suum
39 And he remembered that they are flesh: a wind that goeth and returneth not. 39 sed recordatus est quia caro essent spiritus vadens et non revertens
40 How often did they provoke him in the desert: and move him to wrath in the place without water? 40 quotiens provocaverunt eum in deserto adflixerunt eum in solitudine
41 And they turned back and tempted God: and grieved the holy one of Israel. 41 et conversi sunt et temptaverunt Deum et Sanctum Israhel concitaverunt
42 They remembered not his hand, in the day that he redeemed them from the hand of him that afflicted them: 42 non sunt recordati manus eius diei qua redemit eos a tribulante
43 How he wrought his signs in Egypt, and his wonders in the field of Tanis. 43 qui fecit in Aegypto signa sua et ostenta sua in regione Taneos
44 And he turned their rivers into blood, and their showers that they might not drink. 44 qui convertit in sanguine fluvios eorum et rivos eorum ut non biberent
45 He sent amongst them divers sorts of flies, which devoured them: and frogs which destroyed them. 45 qui inmisit eis genus omne muscarum ut comederent eos et ranas ut disperderent eos
46 And he gave up their fruits to the blast, and their labours to the locust. 46 qui dedit brucho germen eorum et laborem eorum lucustae
47 And he destroyed their vineyards with hail, and their mulberry trees with hoarfrost. 47 qui occidit in grandine vineas eorum et sycomoros eorum in frigore
48 And he gave up their cattle to the hail, and their stock to the fire. 48 qui tradidit grandini pascua eorum et iumenta eorum volucribus
49 And he sent upon them the wrath of his indignation: indignation and wrath and trouble, which he sent by evil angels. 49 qui misit in eos iram furoris sui indignationem et comminationem et angustiam inmissionem angelorum malorum
50 He made a way for a path to his anger: he spared not their souls from death, and their cattle he shut up in death. 50 munivit semitam furori suo non pepercit morti animae eorum et animantia eorum pesti tradidit
51 And he killed all the firstborn in the land of Egypt: the firstfruits of all their labour in the tabernacles of Cham. 51 et percussit omne primogenitum in Aegypto principium partus in tabernaculis Cham
52 And he took away his own people as sheep: and guided them in the wilderness like a flock. 52 et tulit veluti oves populum suum et minavit eos sicut gregem in deserto
53 And he brought them out in hope and they feared not: and the sea overwhelmed their enemies. 53 et duxit eos cum fiducia et absque timore inimicos autem eorum operuit mare
54 And he brought them into the mountain of his sanctuary: the mountain which his right hand had purchased. And he cast out the Gentiles before them: and by lot divided to them their land by a line of distribution. 54 et adduxit eos ad terminum sanctificatum suum montem istum quem possedit dextera eius et eiecit a facie eorum gentes et possidere eos fecit in funiculo hereditatem
55 And he made the tribes of Israel to dwell in their tabernacles. 55 et conlocavit in tabernaculis eorum tribus Israhel
56 Yet they tempted, and provoked the most high God: and they kept not his testimonies. 56 et temptaverunt et provocaverunt Deum excelsum et testimonia eius non custodierunt
57 And they turned away, and kept not the covenant: even like their fathers they were turned aside as a crooked bow. 57 et aversi sunt et praevaricati sunt ut patres eorum incurvati sunt quasi arcus inutilis
58 They provoked him to anger on their hills: and moved him to jealousy with their graven things. 58 et provocaverunt eum in excelsis suis et in sculptilibus suis ad aemulandum concitaverunt
59 God heard, and despised them, and he reduced Israel exceedingly as it were to nothing. 59 audivit Deus et non distulit et proiecit vehementer Israhel
60 And he put away the tabernacle of Silo, his tabernacle where he dwelt among men. 60 et reliquit tabernaculum Selo tentorium quod conlocavit inter homines
61 And he delivered their strength into captivity: and their beauty into the hands of the enemy. 61 tradidit in captivitatem gloriam suam et decorem suum in manu hostis
